## VMED O2 UK Financing I plc in accordance with the VMED O2 Green Bond Framework (as defined herein)

VMED O2 UK Financing I plc (the “Issuer”) is offering $ aggregate principal amount of its % Senior Secured Notes
due 2031 (the “Dollar Notes”), and £ aggregate principal amount of its % Senior Secured Notes due 2031 (the “Sterling
**Notes” and, together with the Dollar Notes, the “Notes”). The Dollar Notes will bear interest at the rate of** % per annum and the
Sterling Notes will bear interest at the rate of % per annum. The Dollar Notes will mature on July 15, 2031. The Sterling Notes will
mature on July 15, 2031. Interest on the Notes will be payable semi-annually in arrear on January 15 and July 15 of each year, beginning on
January 15, 2022.

In accordance with the VMED O2 Green Bond Framework (as defined herein), the Joint Venture (as defined herein) intends to use an
amount equal to the net proceeds of the Notes to finance and/or refinance new and/or existing VM Eligible Green Projects (as defined herein)
and to pay fees and expenses in relation thereto. Accordingly, on June 14, 2021, Sustainalytics, a provider of environmental, social and
governance (“ESG”) research and analysis, evaluated the VMED O2 Green Bond Framework and certified that it aligns with the 2021 Green
Bond Principles (as defined herein) and provided views on the robustness and credibility of the VMED O2 Green Bond Framework (which
views are intended to inform investors in general, and not for a specific investor). See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and the
_Structure—The Notes may not be a suitable investment for all investors seeking exposure to “green” assets” and “Risk Factors—Risks_
_Relating to the Notes and the Structure—Investors may have limited remedies if we fail to allocate an amount equal to the net proceeds from_
_the offering of the Notes to finance and/or refinance new and/or existing VM Eligible Green Projects or to satisfy related reporting_
_requirements and other undertakings”._

On the Issue Date (as defined herein), (i) the proceeds from the offering of the Dollar Notes will be used by the Issuer to fund a U.S.
dollar-denominated loan in a principal amount equal to the aggregate principal amount of the Dollar Notes (the “Finco Loan $”) borrowed
under an additional facility (the “Finco Facility $”) by VMED O2 UK Holdco 4 Limited (the “New VM Credit Facility Borrower”) under
the VM Credit Facility (as defined herein) and (ii) the proceeds from the offering of the Sterling Notes will be used by the Issuer to fund a
pound sterling-denominated loan in a principal amount equal to the aggregate principal amount of the Sterling Notes (the “Finco Loan £”
and, together with Finco Loan $, the “New Finco Loans” and each a “New Finco Loan”) borrowed under an additional facility (the “Finco
**Facility £” and, together with the Finco Facility $, the “New Finco Facilities” and each a “New Finco Facility”) by the New VM Credit**
Facility Borrower under the VM Credit Facility.

On the Issue Date, the obligations of the New VM Credit Facility Borrower under the New Finco Loans will be guaranteed on a senior
basis by the VM Credit Facility Guarantors (as defined herein) and will be secured by the VM Credit Facility Collateral (as defined herein).

The Issuer is a special purpose financing company incorporated for the purpose of issuing the Notes and incurring certain other
indebtedness and will depend upon payments under the New Finco Loans and the applicable Related Agreements (as defined herein) to make
payments under the Notes. The Issuer will apply all payments it receives under the New Finco Loans and the applicable Related Agreements,
including in respect of principal, premiums, interest and additional amounts, if any, to make corresponding payments under the Notes.

The New Finco Facility Accession Agreements (as defined herein) will provide for the payment of certain premiums in connection with
certain voluntary and mandatory prepayments of the applicable New Finco Loans that will enable the Issuer to pay the premiums payable in
respect of corresponding redemptions of the applicable Notes, as described in “Description of the Notes—Redemption and Repurchase”. Some
or all of the Dollar Notes and/or the Sterling Notes may be redeemed at any time prior to July 15, 2026, at a price equal to 100% of the
principal amount of the applicable Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest to (but excluding) the date of redemption and a “makewhole” premium, as described elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Some or all of the Dollar Notes and/or the Sterling Notes may be
redeemed, at any time on or after July 15, 2026, at the redemption prices set forth elsewhere in this offering memorandum. In addition, at any
time prior to July 15, 2026, the Issuer may redeem up to 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Dollar Notes and/or the
Sterling Notes with the net proceeds of one or more specified equity offerings at the redemption prices set forth elsewhere in this offering
memorandum. Prior to July 15, 2026, during each 12-month period commencing on the Issue Date, up to 10% of the original aggregate
principal amount of the Dollar Notes and/or the Sterling Notes may be redeemed at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount
thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest to (but excluding) the date of redemption.

Following a Change of Control (as defined in the VM Credit Facility), the New VM Credit Facility Borrower will be required, at the
election of the Instructing Group under (and as defined in) the VM Credit Facility, to prepay the New Finco Loans at a price equal to 101% of
the principal amount of the applicable New Finco Loan. Following any such repayment, the Issuer will redeem all of the Notes at a
redemption price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest to (but excluding) the date of redemption.
See “Description of the Notes—Redemption and Repurchase—Redemption upon a Change of Control”. In the event of certain asset sales, the


-----

New VM Credit Facility Borrower may elect, at its option, to (i) offer to prepay a principal amount of the applicable New Finco Loan in an aggregate
amount equal to the principal amount of the applicable Notes tendered in the related asset sale offer to be made by the Issuer (not to exceed such New Finco
Loan’s pro rata share of the amount of the applicable available proceeds from the related asset sale) or (ii) subject to the payment of certain premiums,
prepay the New Finco Loans on a pro rata basis in an amount equal to the available proceeds from the related asset sale, and, in each case, the Issuer will
redeem a corresponding amount of the applicable Notes as set forth in “Description of the Notes—Redemption and Repurchase—Disposal Proceeds”.
Further, upon the occurrence of certain changes in tax law, the Issuer may redeem all but not less than all, of the Dollar Notes and/or the Sterling Notes, as
applicable, at a price equal to the principal amount of the applicable Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest to (but excluding) the date of redemption. See
“Description of the Notes—Redemption and Repurchase—Redemption for Changes in Withholding Taxes”.

The Notes will be the senior and limited recourse obligations of the Issuer. On and from the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured by all of the Issuer’s
rights, title and interests in (i) the Finco Loans (including all rights of the Issuer as a VM Credit Facility Lender under the VM Credit Facility and the New
Finco Facility Accession Agreements), (ii) the Deeds of Covenant, (iii) the Fee Letters, (iv) the Expenses Agreement (excluding any transaction fees payable
to the Issuer pursuant thereto and the Issuer’s rights to be indemnified in respect of fees, costs, expenses and any other amounts payable to parties that do not
benefit from the security interests in the Collateral), (v) the Issue Date Amounts Loans and (vi) sums of money held from time to time in all bank accounts of
the Issuer (excluding any transaction fees payable pursuant to the Expenses Agreement) (in each case of the foregoing, as defined in “Description of the
_Notes”) (collectively, the “Collateral”)._

In addition, other than in certain limited circumstances specified herein, holders of the Notes will not have any recourse to the Issuer other than in
respect of amounts received by the Issuer under the VM Credit Facility and the Related Agreements. In each case where amounts of principal, interest and
other amounts (if any) are stated to be payable in respect of the Notes, the obligation of the Issuer to make any such payment shall constitute the obligation
only to account to holders of the Notes for an amount equivalent to sums of principal, interest and other amounts (if any) actually received by or for the
account of the Issuer pursuant to the New Finco Loans and the Related Agreements between the Issuer, the New VM Credit Facility Borrower and/or VMIH
(as defined herein), as the case may be. None of the JV Holdco (as defined herein) or any of its subsidiaries will guarantee or provide any credit support to
the Issuer with respect to its obligations under the Notes. Other than under the limited circumstances described herein, holders of the Notes will not have a
direct claim on the cash flow or assets of the JV Holdco or any of its subsidiaries (other than the Issuer), and none of the JV Holdco or any of its subsidiaries

**Other Financial Measures**

**_Virgin Media Group_**

In this offering memorandum and the information incorporated by reference herein we present “Segment
Adjusted EBITDA” and “OFCF” of the Virgin Media Group, which are not required by, or presented in
accordance with, U.S. GAAP. Segment Adjusted EBITDA and OFCF are the primary measures used by the
Virgin Media Group’s chief operating decision maker and management to evaluate the operating performance of
its businesses. Segment Adjusted EBITDA and OFCF are also key factors that are used by the Virgin Media
Group’s internal decision makers to (i) determine how to allocate resources and (ii) evaluate the effectiveness of
its management for purposes of annual and other incentive compensation plans. As the Virgin Media Group uses
the term, “Segment Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as earnings (loss) before net income tax benefit (expense),
other non-operating income or expenses, net gains (losses) on extinguishment of debt, net realized and unrealized
gains (losses) due to changes in fair value of certain debt, net foreign currency gains (losses), net realized and
unrealized gains (losses) on derivative instruments, net interest expense, net interest income, depreciation and
amortization, share-based compensation, provisions and provision releases related to significant litigation and
impairment, restructuring and other operating items. Other operating items include (i) gains and losses on the
disposition of long-lived assets, (ii) third-party costs directly associated with successful and unsuccessful
acquisitions and dispositions, including legal, advisory and due diligence fees, as applicable, and (iii) other
acquisition-related items, such as gains and losses on the settlement of contingent consideration. As the Virgin
Media Group uses the term, “OFCF” is defined as Segment Adjusted EBITDA less property and equipment
additions. The Virgin Media Group’s internal decision makers believe Segment Adjusted EBITDA and OFCF are
meaningful measures because they represent a transparent view of the Virgin Media Group’s recurring operating
performance that is unaffected by its capital structure and allows management to (a) readily view operating
trends and (b) identify strategies to improve operating performance in the U.K. and Ireland. The Virgin Media
Group believes its Segment Adjusted EBITDA and OFCF measures, which are non-GAAP measures, are useful
to investors because they are each a basis for comparing the Virgin Media Group’s performance with the
performance of other companies in the same or similar industries, although the Virgin Media Group’s measures
may not be directly comparable to similar measures used by other public companies. Segment Adjusted EBITDA
and OFCF should be viewed as measures of operating performance that are a supplement to, and not a substitute
for U.S. GAAP measures of income or loss. Reconciliations of Segment Adjusted EBITDA and OFCF to the
most directly comparable U.S. GAAP financial measure is provided in this offering memorandum. See
“Summary Financial and Operating Data of the Virgin Media Group”.

**_O2 Group_**

In this offering memorandum we present “OIBDA”, “OIBDA Margin”, “OIBDA-CapEx”, “OIBDA-CapEx
Margin” and “Net debt” of the O2 Group, which are not required by, or presented in accordance with IFRS.
OIBDA, OIBDA Margin, OIBDA-CapEx, OIBDA-CapEx Margin and Net debt are the primary measures used
by the O2 Group to evaluate the operating performance of its businesses, make decisions about allocating
resources and to establish operating and strategic targets. As the O2 Group uses the term, OIBDA is calculated
by excluding depreciation and amortization from operating profit. OIBDA Margin is OIBDA calculated as a
percentage of revenue. OIBDA-CapEx is calculated as OIBDA minus capital expenditures. OIBDA-CapEx
Margin is OIBDA-CapEx calculated as a percentage of revenue. Net debt is calculated by subtracting cash and
cash equivalents from total borrowings. Such measures are not required by, or presented in accordance with,
IFRS. The O2 Group believes such measures are useful to investors as they provide one basis for comparing the

xix

O2 Group’s performance with the performance of other companies in the same or similar industries, although
such measures as defined by the O2 Group may not be directly comparable to the same or similar measures used
by other companies. Such measures should be viewed as measures of operating performance that are a
supplement to, and not a substitute for, operating profit, net cash inflow from operating activities and other IFRS
measures of income or cash flows. A reconciliation of OIBDA to operating profit is provided in this offering
memorandum. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of
_the O2 Group—Special Note Regarding Non-IFRS Measures”._

**_Joint Venture_**

**Non-Financial Key Operating Performance Data**

**_Virgin Media Group_**

Each of the Virgin Media Group’s subscribers is counted as a revenue generating unit (“RGU”) for each
broadband communication service subscribed. Thus, a subscriber who receives broadband internet, digital cable
television and fixed-line telephony services from us (regardless of their number of telephony access lines) would
be counted as three RGUs. The Virgin Media Group’s mobile subscribers are counted based on the number of
subscriber identification module (“SIM”) cards in service. The subscriber data of the Virgin Media Group
included in this offering memorandum, including RGUs and average revenue per user (“VM ARPU”), are
determined by the Virgin Media Group’s management, are not part of the VM Annual Combined Financial
Statements or the VM Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements and have not been audited or
otherwise reviewed by an outside independent auditor, consultant or expert or by any of the Initial Purchasers.

**_O2 Group_**

Each connection to any of the O2 Group’s telecommunications services is referred to as an “access”. The
O2 Group believes that it is more useful to count the number of accesses a customer has contracted for, rather
than to count only the number of its customers, who may have multiple fixed or mobile accesses. As such, a
customer that has a fixed-line telephony service and a mobile service is counted as two accesses. The subscriber
data of the O2 Group included in this offering memorandum, including accesses and average revenue per user
(“O2 ARPU”), are determined by the O2 Group’s management, are not part of the O2 Annual Consolidated
Financial Statements or the O2 Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements and have not been audited
or otherwise reviewed by an outside independent auditor, consultant or expert or by any of the Initial Purchasers.

**Joint Venture Overview**

On May 7, 2020, Liberty Global and Telefónica, among others, entered into the Contribution Agreement
and agreed to form a 50:50 joint venture combining Virgin Media’s operations in the U.K. with O2 Holdings’
operations in the U.K. (the “Joint Venture”). The Virgin Media Group’s operations in Ireland (“VM Ireland”)
and certain other less significant operations of the Virgin Media Group are not part of the Joint Venture. The
Joint Venture was consummated on June 1, 2021 (the “JV Closing Date”). See “—The Transactions—Joint
_Venture Transactions”._

The Joint Venture combines the Virgin Media Group’s U.K. fiber-rich broadband network with the O2
Group’s leading mobile operations to create a leading telecommunications provider in the U.K. As of March 31,
2021, on a combined pro forma basis, the Joint Venture would have had 46.5 million video, broadband and
mobile subscribers. For more information regarding the subscriber data for the Joint Venture, see “Unaudited
_Condensed Pro Forma Combined Financial Statements of JV Holdco”._

We believe the Joint Venture benefits from the combined operations of the Virgin Media Group and the O2
Group as follows:

    - well penetrated broadband and digital TV markets, which, together with the potential to migrate mobile
customers from prepaid to postpaid contracts, supports opportunities for fixed-mobile convergence;

    - strong positions in terms of number of subscribers and market share across multiple business segments;

    - opportunity to become a leading enterprise business through the integration of the respective entity’s
expertise and rich product portfolio powered by the Virgin Media Group’s fiber-rich fixed-line network
and the O2 Group’s leading mobile network;

    - strong network infrastructure with a market-leading high-speed broadband network and a mobile
network with substantial spectrum holding; and

    - significant expected efficiencies by achieving key cost, capital expenditure and revenue synergies,
which in sum are expected to deliver substantial synergies valued at an estimated £6.2 billion on a net
present value basis after integration costs;

       - synergy benefits are estimated to include cost, capital expenditure and revenue synergy benefits of
£540 million on an annual basis by the fifth full year following completion of the Joint Venture
Transactions, comprised of approximately £350 million of cost savings, approximately
£80 million of capital expenditure synergies and approximately £110 million of revenue
synergies;


1


-----

       - the key expected sources of cost and capital expenditure synergies include:

          - use of existing infrastructure to provide services for each of the Virgin Media Group’s and
the O2 Group’s customers at lower costs compared with each of the Virgin Media Group’s
and the O2 Group’s standalone and/or wholesale capabilities;

          - migration of Virgin Media’s existing mobile traffic to the O2 Group’s mobile network;

          - combination of regional and national network infrastructures and IT systems;

          - reduction in combined marketing expenditures;

          - potential to reduce general and administration costs; and

          - site rationalization;

       - the key expected sources of revenue synergies are expected to include significant growth through
cross-selling opportunities and scale; and

       - to achieve these synergies, the Joint Venture expects to incur approximately £700 million of
integration costs, substantially all of which are expected to be incurred in the first four years
following completion of the Joint Venture Transactions.

The Joint Venture intends to distribute available cash to its shareholders periodically and is expected to
undertake periodic further recapitalizations, subject to market and operating conditions (including compliance by
the Group with the terms of existing financing arrangements), to maintain a target net leverage ratio between
4.0x to 5.0x.

**_Sustainability Strategy of the Joint Venture_**

The O2 Group’s operations in the U.K. previously fell under Telefónica’s sustainability program and certain
of the Virgin Media Group’s sustainability strategies are designed to support the sustainability targets of Liberty
Global. Following consummation of the Joint Venture on the JV Closing Date, the Joint Venture will review its
existing programs and establish a single sustainability program for the newly combined operations.

**Virgin Media Group Overview**

The Virgin Media Group provides video, broadband internet and fixed-line telephony services in the U.K.
over its broadband communications network and mobile services as a mobile virtual network operator
(“MVNO”). The Virgin Media Group has built out 2.4 million homes in the U.K. since 2015 and its network
covers 52% of the U.K. by homes passed as of March 31, 2021. The Virgin Media Group offers a variety of
broadband services over its cable network, including video, high speed broadband internet and telephony. This
network enables the Virgin Media Group to provide premium digital video services, broadband internet services
and fixed-line telephony services. The key product offer for the Virgin Media Group is its bundled fixed-line
services coupled with mobile voice and mobile data packages, commonly referred to as Fixed-Mobile Converged
bundles.

The Virgin Media Group’s U.K. network passed approximately 15.4 million homes (of which 14.2 million
are passed with HFC and 1.2 million passed with FTTH) and had approximately 5.7 million fixed-line customer
relationships as of March 31, 2021, compared to approximately 5.5 million as of March 31, 2020. In addition, the
Virgin Media Group had approximately 5.5 million broadband internet subscribers in the U.K. as of March 31,
2021, compared to 5.3 million as of March 31, 2020. As of March 31, 2021, the Virgin Media Group had a fixedmobile convergence rate of 26.1% in the U.K., compared to 22.7% as of March 31, 2020, and a leading sector
average revenue per user in the U.K. among its peers.

The fixed-line market in the U.K. is expected to remain stable, with an estimated compound annual revenue
growth rate of 0.6% for 2020-2023 (source: Analysys Mason). FTTH build-out in the U.K. is below levels
observed in other markets, but is expected to accelerate rapidly in the next five years. FTTP and FTTB
technology is expected to increase from approximately 8% of internet connections in the U.K. in 2020 to
approximately 17% by 2023 (source: Analysys Mason).


2


-----

The Virgin Media Group’s revenue and Segment Adjusted EBITDA was £5.1 billion and £2.1 billion,
respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2020, and £1.3 billion and £507.3 million, respectively, for the
three months ended March 31, 2021. In addition, the Virgin Media Group’s property and equipment additions
were £1.1 billion for the year ended December 31, 2020, and £254.7 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2021.

**_Sustainability Strategy of the Virgin Media Group_**

The Virgin Media Group’s sustainability strategy (the “Meaningful Connections Plan”) was launched in
February 2021. This sustainability strategy seeks to utilise the influence of the Virgin Media brand, the skills and
capabilities of its employees and the strength of its network to promote positive societal and environmental
changes. The Virgin Media Group’s sustainability plan will focus on the following three core undertakings for
the next five years (the terms “we,” “our,” and “us” below refer to the Virgin Media Group and its consolidated
subsidiaries):

    - **Better for people: We are aiming to build a business where all our employees and customers feel a**
sense of belonging and that they are being supported. To support this aim, we are creating initiatives
that assist individuals from underrepresented communities to develop skills and access employment
opportunities.

    - **Better for communities: While digital connectivity has increased incrementally, loneliness and**
isolation continue to rise with it. We are looking to bring people and communities closer together by
harnessing the power of our network and brand to help 1.5 million people foster meaningful
connections within their communities by the end of 2025, and intend to focus on supporting unpaid
carers with their experiences of loneliness through a five year partnership with Carers UK. We consider
a connection as “meaningful” where it helps reduce loneliness and build a sense of community
belonging. We will also look to encourage local volunteering as a way of encouraging community
involvement.

    - **Better for the planet: In recognition of the growing effects of human industry on our planet, we are**
looking to shrink our own impact by committing to a zero waste and zero carbon future. We have set a
goal of reaching net zero carbon and zero waste across our operations by the end of 2025.

The Virgin Media Group’s plan is underpinned by:

    - **Better business: We are committed to running our business responsibly by looking beyond our**
proactive environmental and social impact programs and looking to foster positive social and
environmental changes in our quotidian business operations.

For more information regarding the sustainability of the Virgin Media Group, see “Sustainability of the
_Virgin Media Group”._

**O2 Group Overview**

The O2 Group is the U.K.’s largest mobile network operator (based on mobile subscriptions, according to
management estimates) as of March 31, 2021, with over 36 million accesses (including MVNOs and
machine-to-machine connections). The O2 Group pursues a customer-led approach to mobile connectivity,
backed by a strong mobile spectrum position, providing 2G, 3G and 4G voice and data coverage to more than
99% (in at least one band) of the U.K. outdoor population as of March 31, 2021. The O2 Group’s network is
future-ready with a clear path to 5G deployment. Additionally, the O2 Group has access to a single, national grid
of over 17,300 shared mobile sites (under the network sharing arrangement between Telefonica UK Limited and
Vodafone) and further sites which are wholly owned by the O2 Group.

The O2 Group’s revenue and OIBDA was £6.0 billion and £1.8 billion, respectively, for the year ended
December 31, 2020, and £1.4 billion and £0.5 billion, respectively, for the three months ended March 31, 2021.
In addition, the O2 Group’s CapEx was £0.9 billion for the year ended December 31, 2020, and £1.0 billion for
the three months ended March 31, 2021.


3


-----

**_Sustainability Strategy of the O2 Group_**

The O2 Group has a sustainability strategy (the “Blueprint Strategy”). The Blueprint Strategy was
launched in August 2020 and includes long-term targets to reflect the O2 Group’s commitment to reduce its
impact on the environment, and deliver a greener network for customers, by promoting the enabling role of
mobile in delivering a more sustainable future. It sets out its responsibility to society by helping people enjoy a
safer and more positive relationship with technology, and by improving digital access and inclusion. The
Blueprint Strategy also reflects the O2 Group’s commitment to running its business responsibly for its customers,
its people and other key stakeholders, by championing diversity and inclusion, and by building an ethical culture
and maintaining strong community ties.

The Blueprint Strategy has three primary commitments:

    - **Building a greener future by becoming a net zero business by 2025 (with the goal that the O2**
Group’s value chain achieve net zero emissions by 2040) and offering mobile and digital innovation to
customers to make a low-carbon world a reality;

    - **Helping society thrive by promoting greener, more inclusive and resilient communities powered by**
smart technology; and

    - **Leading by example by championing a fair and ethical business from the inside as an inclusive**
employer and adopting ethical decision making as well as creating shared accountability.

To underline the O2 Group’s commitment to contributing to a more sustainable future, the O2 Group has set
itself two climate-action targets as part of its greener future strategic pillar:

    - To achieve net zero emissions for its own operations by 2025, and by 2040 for its external value
chains; and

    - To reduce its value chain emissions by 39% by 2025.

The Blueprint Strategy is aligned with, and contributes to, eight of the United Nations’ Sustainable
Development Goals, which aim to tackle pressing global challenges such as climate change, injustice and
equality, namely:

1. Promoting the use of affordable, safe, sustainable and modern energy for all;

2. Supporting sustainable consumption and production models;

3. Taking urgent action to fight climate change and its impacts;

4. Boosting connectivity and fostering innovation;

5. Reducing inequality and championing inclusion;

6. Enabling communities to benefit from the development and use of smart technologies;

7. Achieving gender equality; and

8. Promoting sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth and decent work for all.

The Blueprint Strategy is also underpinned by a commitment to operating responsibly in everything the O2
Group does. The Blueprint Strategy’s core values of “Bold, Open and Trusted” (representing the O2 Group’s
bold attitude, openness to its customers and people and its strong emphasis on earning the trust of its people and
customers) and its business principles (which form the O2 Group’s ethical code) help guide behaviours at all
levels of the organisation.

For more information regarding the sustainability of the O2 Group, see “Sustainability of the O2 Group”.

**_Overview of the Structure of the Offering_**

On the Issue Date, the Issuer will enter into (i) an accession agreement to the VM Credit Facility, in
substantially the form attached as Annex D to this offering memorandum, with the New VM Credit Facility
Borrower and the VM Credit Facility Agent (the “Finco Facility $ Accession Agreement”), pursuant to which
the Issuer will make available to the New VM Credit Facility Borrower an additional facility under the VM
Credit Facility in a principal amount equal to the aggregate principal amount of the Dollar Notes issued in the
offering and (ii) an accession agreement to the VM Credit Facility, in substantially the form attached as Annex E
to this offering memorandum, with the New VM Credit Facility Borrower and the VM Credit Facility Agent (the
“Finco Facility £ Accession Agreement” and together with the Finco Facility $ Accession Agreement, the
“New Finco Facility Accession Agreements”), pursuant to which the Issuer will make available to the New VM
Credit Facility Borrower an additional facility under the VM Credit Facility in a principal amount equal to the
aggregate principal amount of the Sterling Notes issued in the offering.

The Issuer, as a VM Credit Facility Lender, will be treated the same as all other VM Credit Facility Lenders
and will have benefits, rights and protections that are similar to those benefits, rights and protections afforded to
other VM Credit Facility Lenders. Through the covenants in the Indenture and the security interests over the
Finco Loans (including the New Finco Loans) granted to the Security Trustee on behalf of itself, the Trustee and
the holders of the Notes to secure the Issuer’s obligations under the Notes, the holders of the Notes will be
provided indirectly with the benefits, rights and protections granted to the Issuer as a VM Credit Facility Lender,
including the indirect benefit of the covenants contained in the VM Credit Facility, the guarantees granted by the
VM Credit Facility Guarantors and the VM Credit Facility Collateral. See “Description of the VM Credit Facility
_and the Related Agreements”. Thus, in the case of the ongoing obligations of the Bank Group (as defined in the_
VM Credit Facility) under the VM Credit Facility, the Issuer will be treated in the same way as the other VM
Credit Facility Lenders, with the right to vote as part of the lending group on the basis described in this
“Description of the Notes” and to receive principal and interest on the New Finco Loans, which it will in turn use
to make payments on the Notes. For a description of procedures under the Indenture and the New Finco Facility
Accession Agreements relating to the voting rights of holders of the relevant series of Notes with respect to
decisions under the VM Credit Facility, see “Description of the Notes—Amendment, Supplement and Waiver—
_To the VM Credit Facility or the New Finco Facility Accession Agreements”._

Under the VM Credit Facility, to the extent the Bank Group is in compliance with certain financial
covenants, the borrowers under the VM Credit Facility, at their discretion and without the consent of the VM
Credit Facility Lenders, are permitted to incur additional pari passu indebtedness pursuant to additional VM
Credit Facility Loans (as defined in “Description of the Notes”) under the VM Credit Facility, which benefit from
the protections provided to all VM Credit Facility Lenders, including the representations and warranties,
covenants, guarantees and security provided thereunder. For a further description of the VM Credit Facility, see
“Description of the VM Credit Facility and the Related Agreements”. The VM Credit Facility is attached as
Annex A to this offering memorandum.

On the Issue Date, (i) the net proceeds of the offering of the Dollar Notes, together with the fees payable to
the Issuer (if any) from the New VM Credit Facility Borrower under the Finco Facility $ Fee Letter, will be used
by the Issuer to fund a loan (the “Finco Loan $”) borrowed under an additional facility (the “Finco Facility $”)
established pursuant to the Finco Facility $ Accession Agreement under the VM Credit Facility and (ii) the net
proceeds of the offering of the Sterling Notes, together with the fees payable to the Issuer (if any) from the New
VM Credit Facility Borrower under the Finco Facility £ Fee Letter, will be used by the Issuer to fund a loan (the
“Finco Loan £” and together with the Finco Loan $, the “New Finco Loans”) borrowed under an additional
facility (the “Finco Facility £” and together with the Finco Facility $, the “New Finco Facilities”) established
pursuant to the Finco Facility £ Accession Agreement under the VM Credit Facility, and the Issuer will become a
VM Credit Facility Lender.

The principal amount of the Dollar Notes due at maturity, as well as the maturity date, rate of interest and
currency, among other things, will be identical to the corresponding provisions of the Finco Loan $ and the
principal amount of the Sterling Notes due at maturity, as well as the maturity date, rate of interest and currency,
among other things, will be identical to the corresponding provisions of the Finco Loan £.

On the Issue Date, the Trustee will accede to the Collateral Sharing Agreement that governs the relative
rights of creditors under the Notes (including any Additional Notes) and any Additional Debt of the Issuer that


5


-----

benefits from the shared Collateral on a pari passu basis. Pursuant to the Collateral Sharing Agreement, all
proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral will be shared on a pari passu basis by the holders of the Notes
(including any Additional Notes) and the creditors of all Additional Debt of the Issuer that benefits from the
shared Collateral on a pari passu basis, including the Existing JV Notes. The Collateral Sharing Agreement sets
out, among other things, (i) the relevant ranking of certain debt of the Issuer, (ii) the consent level of the senior
creditors required to cast votes and exercise their rights in respect of consents, instructions and remedies under
the Indenture, the Notes, the Notes Security Documents and the other debt instruments or agreements sharing in
the Collateral (including the Existing JV Notes), when enforcement action can be taken in respect of the
Collateral by the Security Trustee and (iii) turnover provisions. The holders and/or lenders, as applicable, of a
majority in aggregate principal amount of all Notes (including any Additional Notes) and all Additional Debt
then outstanding will control any enforcement actions in respect of the Collateral.

**_Joint Venture Transactions_**

The transactions described under this “—Joint Venture Transactions” are referred to, collectively, herein as
the “Joint Venture Transactions”.

_Overview_

On May 7, 2020, Liberty Global, Liberty Global Europe 2 Limited (“Liberty Global Europe”), Liberty
Global Holdco Limited, Telefónica and Telefonica O2 Holdings Limited (“Telefonica O2”) entered into a
contribution agreement (the “Contribution Agreement”) pursuant to the terms of which the parties agreed to
form the Joint Venture. The Contribution Agreement includes customary representations, warranties, covenants
and indemnification obligations of Liberty Global and Telefónica relating to each of their contributed businesses.

As part of the Joint Venture, on June 1, 2021, Liberty Global and Telefónica (among other parties) entered
into a shareholders agreement (the “Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement”) whereby each of Liberty Global
and Telefónica directly or indirectly hold 50% of the issued share capital of VMED O2 UK Limited (the “JV
**Holdco”) and to which Liberty Global Europe contributed the operations of the Virgin Media Group (other than**
the VM Excluded Business) (the “Virgin Media Contribution”) and Telefonica O2 contributed the O2 Group
(the “O2 Contribution” and, together with the Virgin Media Contribution, the “Contributions”). The
Contributions were consummated on June 1, 2021 (the “JV Closing Date”). Each of Liberty Global Europe and
Telefonica O2 implemented certain reorganization steps prior to the JV Closing Date. In particular, the VM
Excluded Business were not part of the Virgin Media Contribution and were transferred out of the Virgin Media
Group prior to the JV Closing Date. See “Unaudited Condensed Pro Forma Combined Financial Statements of
_JV Holdco”. The Virgin Media Contribution included all existing third-party indebtedness of the Virgin Media_
Group and the O2 Contribution included all existing third-party indebtedness of the O2 Group, in each case as of
the JV Closing Date.

Each of Liberty Global and Telefónica guarantee the performance of Liberty Global Europe and Telefonica
O2, respectively, under each of the Contribution Agreement and the Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement.

The Joint Venture Transactions are not expected to constitute a Change of Control under (and as defined in)
the Existing VM Notes, the VM Credit Facility or any other existing indebtedness of the Virgin Media Group or
the O2 Group.

_Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement_

The Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement provides that the initial board of directors of the Joint Venture
will be composed of eight directors, with four directors designated by each of Liberty Global Europe and
Telefonica O2. The Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement provided that, in general, most decisions of the board
of directors will require the approval of at least one individual designated by both Liberty Global Europe and
Telefonica O2, whereas certain decisions as to “Reserved Matters” will require the approval of both Liberty
Global Europe and Telefonica O2, either directly or through their designees to the board of directors. Such
“Reserved Matters” under the Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement include: (i) changes in the constituent
documents of the JV Holdco, capital stock, certain executive management matters, or branding of the Joint
Venture; (ii) certain material transactions, including transfers of all shares in the JV Holdco and acquisitions and
dispositions over a certain threshold; (iii) the adoption of any new business plan or amendment to any current


6


-----

business plan (including with respect to the budget) of the Joint Venture; and (iv) certain other material business,
investing and financing decisions of the Joint Venture.

The Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement provides that the Chairman of the board of directors will
alternate every two years between a Liberty Global Europe director and a Telefonica O2 director. The initial
Chairman of the board of directors of the Joint Venture, Mr. Mike Fries, the CEO of Liberty Global, was
designated by Liberty Global Europe. Mr. José María Álvarez-Pallete López, the CEO of Telefónica, was
designated as a director by Telefonica O2. The remaining directors and executive officers have been selected and
appointed by Liberty Global Europe and Telefonica O2 in accordance with the Joint Venture Shareholders
Agreement. See “Management and Governance of the Joint Venture”.

Pursuant to the Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement, the Joint Venture will be required to make regular
cash distributions to the shareholders of the JV Holdco on a pro rata basis equal to the unrestricted cash of the
Joint Venture (subject to the Joint Venture maintaining minimum cash levels and complying certain leverage
ratios and the terms of its financing arrangements).

The Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement includes a lock-in period of three years from the date of the
agreement, during which the shareholders of the JV Holdco are not permitted to transfer their shares other than in
limited circumstances. Each shareholder of the JV Holdco has a customary right of first offer rights and dragalong rights, which shall apply following the fifth anniversary of the Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement and
will be subject to non-compete and non-solicit undertakings subject to certain carve-outs.

_Intra-Group Services_

Following the JV Closing Date, the Joint Venture Parents have agreed to provide ongoing services to the
Joint Venture, primarily consisting of technology and innovation-related services, procurement, brand
management and other support services. The annual charges by the Joint Venture Parents for these services will
ultimately depend on the actual level of services required by the Joint Venture. In addition, the JV Holdco has
entered into a brand license agreement in respect of the use of the Joint Venture of the “O2” and “Telefónica”
brands.

_Joint Venture Financing Transactions_

As part of the Joint Venture Transactions, the Issuer issued the Existing JV Notes and, on the JV Closing
Date, the proceeds from the issuance of the Existing JV Notes were used by the Issuer to fund the Existing Finco
Loans pursuant to the applicable Existing Finco Facilities. See “Description of the VM Credit Facility and the
_Related Agreements—VM Credit Facility” and “Description of Other Debt—Existing JV Notes”._

Concurrently with the issuance of the Existing JV Notes, the New VM Credit Facility Borrower established
(i) a £1,500 million aggregate principal amount pound sterling-denominated term loan A as an Additional
Facility under (and as defined in) the VM Credit Facility (“Facility P”) and (ii) a €750 million aggregate
principal amount euro-denominated term loan B as an Additional Facility under (and as defined in) the VM
Credit Facility (“Facility R”). In addition, concurrently with the issuance of the Existing JV Notes, Virgin Media
Bristol LLC established a $1,300 million aggregate principal amount U.S. dollar-denominated term loan B as an
Additional Facility under (and as defined in) the VM Credit Facility (“Facility Q” and together with Facility P
and Facility R, the “JV Financing VM Credit Facilities”). See “Description of the VM Credit Facility and the
_Related Agreements—VM Credit Facility”._

The gross proceeds from borrowings under the Existing Finco Facilities and the JV Financing VM Credit
Facilities were used on the JV Closing Date to finance the Joint Venture Transactions including, but not limited
to, the financing of equalization payments required in connection with the Joint Venture Transactions, to pay fees
and expenses in connection with the Joint Venture Transactions and otherwise for general corporate and/or
working capital purposes of the Joint Venture.

The foregoing transactions are referred to, collectively, herein as the “JV Financing Transactions”.

**Other Transactions**

The Group continually evaluates different financing alternatives and may decide to enter into new credit
facilities, access the debt capital markets, incur other indebtedness or enter into liability management
transactions, including vendor financing transactions by a special purpose entity and any related senior unsecured
credit facilities, from time to time, including prior to, or within a short time period after, the Issue Date (the
“Potential Financing Transactions”). The cash proceeds, if any, of any Potential Financing Transactions may
be used for the redemption, refinancing, repayment or prepayment of existing indebtedness of any member of the
Group, the payment of any fees and expenses in connection therewith or the other transactions related thereto,
and/or distributions or other payments to direct or indirect parent companies. The indebtedness under any such
Potential Financing Transactions by the Group would be incurred in compliance with the applicable covenants
under the VM Credit Facility, the indentures governing the Existing VM Notes and the Existing VM Financing
Facilities. After giving effect to any such incurrence in compliance with the applicable covenants, including in
connection with permitted refinancing debt, permitted acquisition debt or other exceptions to the restriction on

(1) The Issuer is a financing company formed for the primary purpose of the offering of the Existing JV Notes,
the Notes and any other Additional Debt and is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the JV Holdco. The Issuer is
not part of the Bank Group and is not subject to the restrictive covenants in the VM Credit Facility or the
indentures governing the Existing VM Senior Secured Notes or the Existing VM Senior Notes. The
Indenture will contain covenants with respect to restrictions on the business activities of the Issuer,
maintenance of the existence of the Issuer, listing, minimum period for consents under loan documents,
payments for consent, amendments to loan documents, information and impairment of liens. See
“Description of the Notes”.
(2) The Notes will be the senior and limited recourse obligations of the Issuer. On and from the Issue Date, the
Notes will be secured by all of the Issuer’s rights, title and interests in (i) the Finco Loans (including all
rights of the Issuer as a VM Credit Facility Lender under the VM Credit Facility and the New Finco Facility
Accession Agreements), (ii) the Deeds of Covenant, (iii) the Fee Letters, (iv) the Expenses Agreement
(excluding any transaction fees payable to the Issuer pursuant thereto and the Issuer’s rights to be
indemnified in respect of fees, costs, expenses and any other amounts payable to parties that do not benefit
from the security interests in the Collateral), (v) the Issue Date Amounts Loans and (vi) sums of money held
from time to time in all bank accounts of the Issuer (excluding any transaction fees payable pursuant to the
Expenses Agreement) (collectively, the “Collateral”). See “Description of the Notes—Note Collateral”.
The Collateral Sharing Agreement provides that the security interests in the Collateral may be enforced only
upon an acceleration of the amounts due under the Notes following an Event of Default under (and as
defined in) the Indenture, subject to and in accordance with the terms of the Collateral Sharing Agreement.

(a) Segment Adjusted EBITDA and OFCF are the primary measures used by the Virgin Media Group’s chief
operating decision maker and management to evaluate the operating performance of its businesses. Segment
Adjusted EBITDA and OFCF are also key factors that are used by the Virgin Media Group’s internal
decision makers to (i) determine how to allocate resources and (ii) evaluate the effectiveness of its
management for purposes of annual and other incentive compensation plans. As the Virgin Media Group
uses the term, “Segment Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as earnings (loss) before net income tax benefit
(expense), other non-operating income or expenses, net gains (losses) on modification and extinguishment
of debt, net realized and unrealized gains (losses) due to changes in fair value of certain debt, net foreign
currency gains (losses), net realized and unrealized gains (losses) on derivative instruments, net interest
expense, net interest income, depreciation and amortization, share-based compensation, provisions and
provision releases related to significant litigation and impairment, restructuring and other operating items.
Other operating items include (i) gains and losses on the disposition of long-lived assets, (ii) third-party
costs directly associated with successful and unsuccessful acquisitions and dispositions, including legal,
advisory and due diligence fees, as applicable, and (iii) other acquisition-related items, such as gains and
losses on the settlement of contingent consideration. As the Virgin Media Group uses the term, “OFCF” is
defined as Segment Adjusted EBITDA less property and equipment additions. The Virgin Media Group’s
internal decision makers believe Segment Adjusted EBITDA and OFCF are meaningful measures because
they represent a transparent view of the Virgin Media Group’s recurring operating performance that is
unaffected by its capital structure and allows management to (1) readily view operating trends and
(2) identify strategies to improve operating performance in the U.K. and Ireland. The Virgin Media Group
believes its Segment Adjusted EBITDA and OFCF measures, which are non-U.S. GAAP measures, are
useful to investors because they are each a basis for comparing the Virgin Media Group’s performance with
the performance of other companies in the same or similar industries, although the Virgin Media Group’s
measures may not be directly comparable to similar measures used by other public companies. Segment
Adjusted EBITDA and OFCF should be viewed as measures of operating performance that are a supplement
to, and not a substitute for, U.S. GAAP measures of income. Reconciliations of Segment Adjusted EBITDA
and OFCF to the most directly comparable U.S. GAAP financial measure are as follows:

**UNAUDITED CONDENSED PRO FORMA COMBINED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS OF JV HOLDCO**

The accompanying unaudited condensed pro forma combined financial statements of JV Holdco reflect the
pro forma effects of the agreement between Liberty Global plc (“Liberty Global”) and Telefónica S.A.
(“Telefónica”) to form a 50:50 joint venture (the “Joint Venture”), including the contribution by (i) Liberty
Global of Virgin Media Inc. and its subsidiaries’ (“Virgin Media”) operations in the U.K. (the “Virgin Media
**Contributed Entities”) and (ii) Telefónica of its mobile operations in the U.K., which comprise O2 Holdings**
Limited (“O2 Holdings”) and its consolidated subsidiaries (collectively, the “O2 Group”) (collectively, the
“Joint Venture Transactions”).

Upon formation, the Joint Venture recognized the assets and liabilities of the contributed businesses at their
then fair values, resulting in a new basis of accounting. The accompanying unaudited condensed pro forma
combined statement of financial position as of March 31, 2021 gives effect to the Joint Venture Transactions as if
such transactions had occurred on such date. The accompanying unaudited condensed pro forma combined
statements of operations for the three months ended March 31, 2021 and for the year ended December 31, 2020
give effect to the Joint Venture Transactions as if such transactions had occurred on January 1, 2020. No pro
forma effect has been given for the JV Financing Transactions, the VM Revolving Credit Facility Transactions,
the offering of the Notes or, in each case, the use of proceeds therefrom, each as described and defined elsewhere
in this offering memorandum. These unaudited condensed pro forma combined financial statements have been
prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union
(“IFRS”).

Pursuant to a shareholders agreement (the “Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement”) entered into upon
formation of the Joint Venture, Liberty Global and Telefónica will charge fees for certain services that each
entity will provide to the Joint Venture. These unaudited condensed pro forma combined financial statements
give effect to the estimated amounts expected to be charged to the Joint Venture pursuant to the Joint Venture
Shareholders Agreement.

The unaudited condensed pro forma combined results presented herein do not purport to be indicative of the
financial position and results of operations that the Joint Venture will obtain in the future, or that the Joint
Venture would have obtained were these transactions effective as of the dates indicated above. The pro forma
adjustments are based upon currently available information and certain assumptions that the Joint Venture
believes are reasonable, but may differ from actual amounts. The Joint Venture has not yet completed its
valuations of the underlying fair values of its combined assets and liabilities. Such valuations can result in
material changes to the underlying historical assets and liabilities and have a material effect on the results of
operations attributable to changes to depreciation and amortization.

The “Virgin Media Group” comprises (i) Virgin Media and certain other wholly-owned subsidiaries of
Liberty Global and (ii) UPC Broadband Ireland Ltd and its subsidiaries (“VM Ireland”), which is another
wholly-owned subsidiary of Liberty Global that provides communications services in Ireland. These unaudited
condensed pro forma combined financial statements have been derived from, and should be read in conjunction
with, (i) the Virgin Media Group’s audited combined financial statements as of December 31, 2020 and 2019 and
for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 (the “VM Annual Combined Financial Statements”),
(ii) the Virgin Media Group’s unaudited condensed combined financial statements as of March 31, 2021 and for
the three months ended March 31, 2021 and 2020 (the “VM Interim Condensed Combined Financial
**Statements”), (iii) O2 Holdings’ audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the years ended**
December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 (the “O2 Annual Consolidated Financial Statements”) and (iv) O2
Holdings’ unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements as of March 31, 2021 and for the three months
ended March 31, 2021 and 2020 (the “O2 Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements”), each
incorporated by reference or included elsewhere herein. The VM Annual Combined Financial Statements and the
VM Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the U.S. (“U.S. GAAP”) and, due to the fact that VM Ireland was a “restricted
subsidiary” under the provisions of the facilities agreement and bond indentures governing the debt of the Virgin
Media Group during the applicable periods, such financial statements were prepared on a combined basis. The
O2 Annual Consolidated Financial Statements and the O2 Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements
have been prepared in accordance with IFRS.

to changes in property, plant and equipment, net, customer relationships, spectrum licenses, contract assets
and liabilities, goodwill, debt liabilities and deferred income taxes. To the extent that additional value is
allocated to assets with finite lives, the final measurement of assets and liabilities could result in additional
depreciation and/or amortization expense that in turn would result in lower operating income and earnings
from continuing operations. For example, a £100.0 million increase in the value allocated to intangible
assets with an average remaining estimated useful life of ten years would result in additional annual
amortization expense of £10.0 million.

(6) Amounts represent adjustments to decrease cost of services associated with deferred commissions as a
result of the application of the new basis of accounting to contract assets.

(7) Represents (i) the elimination of the (a) historical related-party fees and allocations charged by Liberty
Global to the Virgin Media Group for services that generally relate to management, finance, legal, technology
and other services that support the Virgin Media Group’s operations (£77.6 million and £300.7 million for the
three months ended March 31, 2021 and year ended December 31, 2020, respectively) and (b) historical fees
charged by Telefónica to the O2 Group (£10.0 million and £40.0 million for the three months ended March 31,
2021 and year ended December 31, 2020, respectively) and (ii) estimated amounts to be charged by Liberty
Global and Telefónica to the Joint Venture pursuant to the Joint Venture Shareholders Agreement associated with
the ongoing services expected to be provided to the Joint Venture, primarily consisting of technology and
innovation-related services, procurement, brand management and other support services (£33.0 million and
£134.0 million charged by Liberty Global for the three months ended March 31, 2021 and year ended
December 31, 2020, respectively, and £10.0 million and £40.0 million charged by Telefónica for the three
months ended March 31, 2021 and year ended December 31, 2020, respectively).

(8) Represents (i) adjustments to increase amortization expense of £360.1 million and £1,440.4 million for
the three months ended March 31, 2021 and year ended December 31, 2020, respectively, which amounts reflect
the difference between (a) the amortization expense associated with the Joint Venture’s customer relationships
intangible asset resulting from the application of the new basis of accounting and (b) the historical amortization
expense associated with the customer relationships intangible asset of the Virgin Media Contributed Entities of
£19.4 million and £77.6 million, respectively, and (ii) net decreased amortization expense of £1.6 million and
£6.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 and year ended December 31, 2020, respectively,
associated with the net increase to the O2 Group’s spectrum licenses intangible asset as a result of the application
of the new basis of accounting. The amortization is computed on a straight-line basis using a weighted average
estimated useful life of 6.0 years for customer relationships and estimated useful lives ranging from 0.8 years to
17.1 years for spectrum licenses. An increase (decrease) in the estimated fair value allocated to the customer
relationships intangible assets of £100.0 million would result in higher (lower) annual amortization expense of
£16.7 million. An increase in the estimated useful life used to amortize the acquisition accounting adjustment to
customer relationships intangible assets of one year would result in lower annual amortization expense of
£216.9 million, while a decrease of one year would result in higher annual amortization expense of
£303.6 million.

(9) Represents the estimated income tax impacts associated with the pro forma adjustments presented
herein. These income tax impacts have been computed based on a U.K. statutory tax rate of 19.0%.

due 2031.

**Sterling Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** £ aggregate principal amount of % Senior Secured Notes
due 2031.

2021.

**Dollar Notes Issue Price . . . . . . . . . . . .** %.

**Sterling Notes Issue Price . . . . . . . . . . .** %.

**Dollar Notes Interest Rate . . . . . . . . . .** %.

**Sterling Notes Interest Rate . . . . . . . . .** %.

**Interest Payment Dates . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Semi-annually in arrear on January 15 and July 15 of each year,
commencing January 15, 2022. Interest will accrue from, and
including, the Issue Date.

**Maturity Date . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Dollar Notes will mature on July 15, 2031. The Sterling Notes
will mature on July 15, 2031.

**Denominations . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Each Dollar Note will be issued in a minimum denomination of

excess thereof.

Each Sterling Note will be issued in a minimum denomination of
£100,000 in principal amount and integral multiples of £1,000 in
excess thereof.

**Ranking of the Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will:

                         - be senior and limited recourse obligations of the Issuer;

                         - rank pari passu in right of payment with any future indebtedness
of the Issuer that is not subordinated to the Notes, including the
Existing JV Notes;

                         - have the benefit of the security as described below under
“—Collateral”;

                         - be subject to the Limited Recourse Restrictions as described
under “—Limited Recourse Restrictions” below; and

                         - be effectively subordinated to any future indebtedness of the
Issuer that is secured by liens senior to the liens securing the
Notes, or secured by property and assets that do not secure the
Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets
securing such indebtedness.


30


-----

**Limited Recourse Restrictions . . . . . . .** Except under the limited circumstances specified under “Description
_of the Notes—Events of Default and Remedies”, the obligations of the_
Issuer under the Indenture, the Notes, the Notes Security Documents
and the Collateral Sharing Agreement will be solely to make
payments of amounts in aggregate equivalent to the amounts actually
received by or for the account of the Issuer from the New VM Credit
Facility Borrower and/or VMIH under the VM Credit Facility and the
Related Agreements. As such, the Issuer will be wholly dependent
upon payments from the New VM Credit Facility Borrower, which
payments will be guaranteed by the VM Credit Facility Guarantors,
under each of the New Finco Loans, other than certain amounts due
on the Notes (such as prepayment premiums and additional amounts,
if any) which will be financed by the New VM Credit Facility
Borrower and/or VMIH pursuant to the relevant Related Agreement,
in order to service its obligations under the Notes.

In addition, other than under the limited circumstances described
under “Description of the Notes—Events of Default and Remedies”,
holders of the Notes will not have a direct claim on the cash flow or
assets of the Group (other than the Issuer) and none of the JV Holdco
or any of its subsidiaries (other than the Issuer) have any obligation,
contingent or otherwise, to pay amounts due under the Notes, or to
make funds available to the Issuer for those payments, other than the
obligations of the New VM Credit Facility Borrower and the VM
Credit Facility Guarantors to make payments to the Issuer under the
VM Credit Facility and the Related Agreements, as applicable.

No member of the Group will guarantee the Issuer’s obligations under
the Notes.

**Collateral . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** On and from the Issue Date, the holders of the Notes will benefit
directly from security interests granted to the Security Trustee on
behalf of itself, the Trustee and the holders of the Notes in the
following rights, property and assets (the “Collateral”):

                         - all of the Issuer’s rights, title and interests in the Finco Loans
(including all rights of the Issuer as a VM Credit Facility Lender
under the VM Credit Facility and the New Finco Facility
Accession Agreements);

                         - all of the Issuer’s rights, title and interests in the Deeds of
Covenant;

                         - all of the Issuer’s rights, title and interests in the Fee Letters;

                         - all of the Issuer’s rights, title and interests in the Expenses
Agreement (excluding any transaction fees payable to the Issuer
pursuant thereto and the Issuer’s rights to be indemnified in
respect of fees, costs, expenses and any other amounts payable to
parties that do not benefit from the security interests in the
Collateral);

                         - all of the Issuer’s rights, title and interests in the Issue Date
Amounts Loans; and

                         - sums of money held from time to time in all bank accounts of the
Issuer (excluding any transaction fees payable pursuant to the
Expenses Agreement).

See “Description of the Notes—Notes Collateral”.


31


-----

The Issuer, as a VM Credit Facility Lender, will be treated the same
as all other VM Credit Facility Lenders and will have benefits, rights
and protections that are similar to those benefits, rights and
protections afforded to other VM Credit Facility Lenders. Through
the covenants in the Indenture and the security interests over the
Finco Loans (including the New Finco Loans) granted to secure the
Issuer’s obligations under the Notes, the holders of the Notes will be
provided indirectly with the benefits, rights and protections granted to
the Issuer as a VM Credit Facility Lender, including the indirect
benefit of the covenants contained in the VM Credit Facility and the
guarantees and security granted for the benefit of the VM Credit
Facility Lenders. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and
_the Structure—The security interest in the VM Credit Facility_
_Collateral securing the New Finco Loans will not be granted directly_
_to the holders of the Notes” for more information._

The Collateral Sharing Agreement provides that the security interests in
the Collateral may be enforced only upon an acceleration of the
amounts due under the Notes following an Event of Default under (and
as defined in) the Indenture, subject to and in accordance with the terms
of the Collateral Sharing Agreement. Neither the Trustee nor the
holders of the Notes may, individually or collectively, take any direct
action to enforce any rights in their favor under the Notes Security
Documents. The Trustee and the holders of the Notes may only take
action to enforce the Notes Security Documents through the Security
Trustee and the Collateral Sharing Agreement. In addition, pursuant to
the Collateral Sharing Agreement, the ability of the Security Trustee to
enforce the security interests in the Collateral will be restricted and will
be at the discretion of the relevant creditors. See “Description of the
_Collateral Sharing Agreement” for more information._

**VM Credit Facility Guarantors . . . . . .** On the date of this offering memorandum, the VM Credit Facility
Guarantors are the only guarantors of the obligations of the Obligors
(as defined in the VM Credit Facility) under the VM Credit Facility
(subject to certain specified guarantee limitations, including, but not
limited to, the exclusion of liability to the extent that such guarantee
would constitute unlawful financial assistance under applicable law).

In addition, the VM Credit Facility requires that additional members
of the Bank Group become guarantors under the VM Credit Facility,
(a) in the event that they become Material Subsidiaries (as defined in
the VM Credit Facility), or (b) where necessary in order to ensure that
the aggregate earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and
amortization of the Obligors (on an unconsolidated basis and
excluding intra-group items) equal or exceed, respectively, 80% of
the consolidated EBITDA (excluding for the purposes of this
calculation any EBITDA attributable to any Joint Venture (as defined
in the VM Credit Facility)) of the Bank Group (the “VM Credit
**Facility 80% Security Test”). As of March 31, 2021, after giving**
effect to the Transactions, the VM Credit Facility Guarantors
represented more than 90% of the pro forma combined total assets of
the Group as of March 31, 2021, and more than 90% of the pro forma
combined revenue of the Group for the three months ended March 31,
2021. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and the
_Structure—Insolvency laws and other limitations on the VM Credit_
_Facility_ _Guarantees_ _may_ _adversely_ _affect_ _their_ _validity_ _and_
_enforceability”._


32


-----

**VM Credit Facility Collateral . . . . . . .** Each of the New Finco Loans will be secured by the security interests
on all of the assets of the Bank Group that are granted to the VM
Credit Facility Security Trustee to secure the VM Credit Facility. The
VM Credit Facility is, or will be, primarily secured by all or
substantially all assets of the Bank Group; provided that, on or after
the Asset Security Release Date (as defined in the VM Credit
Facility), the security granted to secure the VM Credit Facility will be
limited to (i) share pledges over all of the capital stock of the
Borrowers and the other Obligors under (and each as defined in) the
VM Credit Facility and (ii) a pledge of rights of the relevant creditors
in relation to certain intercompany loans. For a description of the VM
Credit Facility Collateral, see “Description of the VM Credit Facility
_and the Related Agreements—VM Credit Facility—Guarantees and_
_Security”._

**Mandatory Redemption on a Change**
**in Control . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Following a Change of Control (as defined in the VM Credit
Facility), the New VM Credit Facility Borrower will be required, at
the election of the Instructing Group under (and as defined in) the
VM Credit Facility, to prepay the New Finco Loans at a price equal to
101% of the principal amount of the applicable New Finco Loan.
Following any such repayment, the Issuer will redeem all of the Notes
at a redemption price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof,
plus accrued and unpaid interest to (but excluding) the date of
redemption. See “Description _of_ _the_ _Notes—Redemption_ _and_
_Repurchase—Redemption upon a Change of Control”._

**Optional Redemption . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** In the event that all or any portion of any New Finco Loan is
voluntarily prepaid by the New VM Credit Facility Borrower
pursuant to Clause 11 (Voluntary Prepayment) of the VM Credit
Facility (an “Early **Redemption** **Event”),** subject to and in
accordance with the terms of the VM Credit Facility and the
applicable New Finco Facility Accession Agreement, the New Finco
Facility Accession Agreements will provide for the payment of
certain additional payments to be made to the Issuer that correspond
to the premiums payable to holders of the applicable Notes upon early
redemption, as described below.

At any time prior to July 15, 2026, with respect to the Finco Loan $,
and at any time prior to July 15, 2026, with respect to the Finco Loan
£, upon the occurrence of an Early Redemption Event in respect of
the applicable New Finco Loan, the Issuer will redeem (i) an
aggregate principal amount of Dollar Notes equal to the principal
amount of the Finco Loan $ prepaid in such Early Redemption Event
(not to exceed an amount equal to 10% of the original aggregate
principal amount of the Dollar Notes (including Additional Dollar
Notes, if any)) and/or (ii) an aggregate principal amount of the
Sterling Notes equal to the principal amount of the Finco Loan £
prepaid in such Early Redemption Event (not to exceed an amount
equal to 10% of the original aggregate principal amount of the
Sterling Notes (including Additional Sterling Notes, if any)) in each
case, during each twelve month period commencing on the Issue
Date, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of
the applicable Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest to
(but excluding) the date of redemption. See “Description of the
_Notes—Redemption and Repurchase—Optional Redemption”._

**Additional Amounts; Tax**
**Redemption . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** All payments in respect of the Notes will be made without
withholding or deduction for any taxes or other governmental
charges, except to the extent required by law. If withholding or
deduction is required by law, subject to certain exceptions, the Issuer
will pay Additional Amounts (as defined in the “Description of the
_Notes”) so that the net amount you receive is no less than that which_
you would have received in the absence of such withholding or
deduction. See “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes”.
Subject to certain exceptions, the Issuer may redeem the applicable
series of Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, upon giving
prior notice, at a price equal to the principal amount of the Notes
redeemed plus interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but
excluding, the date of redemption, in the event of an optional
prepayment of a New Finco Loan pursuant to Clause 10.4 (Right of
_Repayment and Cancellation in Relation to a Single Lender) of the_
VM Credit Facility or if certain changes in tax law impose certain
withholding taxes on amounts payable on the Notes, and, as a result,
the Issuer is required to pay Additional Amounts with respect to such
withholding taxes. See “Description of the Notes—Redemption and
_Repurchases—Redemption for Changes in Withholding Taxes”._

**Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Issuer will issue the Notes under the Indenture. The Indenture

listing, minimum period for consents under loan documents,
payments for consent, amendments to loan documents to be applied

New Finco Facility Accession Agreements. The voting method to be
used to determine the voting position of the Issuer on any matter
subject to a lender vote under the VM Credit Facility is described
under “Description of the Notes—Amendment, Supplement and

_Accession Agreements”._

Each of the New Finco Facility Accession Agreements contains the
consent of the Issuer, as a VM Credit Facility Lender, to certain
significant amendments to the VM Credit Facility and the
Intercreditor Deeds set forth in Schedules 4, 5, 6 and 7 to each of the
New Finco Facility Accession Agreements (in the form attached as
Annexes D and E to this offering memorandum (the “VM Credit
**Facility Amendments”)). The VM Credit Facility Amendments**
include material modifications to certain affirmative and negative
covenants, financial maintenance covenants and related definitions,
representations and warranties, events of default, administrative
provisions and provisions relating to the security package securing the
VM Credit Facility and the approval of the New Group Intercreditor
Agreement (in substantially the form attached as Annex C to this
offering memorandum). The VM Credit Facility Amendments are
generally less restrictive and provide greater flexibility to the Bank
Group than the provisions currently included in the VM Credit
Facility. Specifically, the VM Credit Facility Amendments include,
but are not limited to, the following (capitalized terms used in the

following description have the meanings currently provided in the

**Risks Relating to Our Industry and Our Business**

**_We operate in increasingly competitive markets, and there is a risk that we will not be able to effectively_**
**_compete with other service providers._**

The markets for broadband internet, cable television, fixed-line telephony, mobile and value-add services in
which we operate are highly competitive and, in certain markets, we compete with established companies that
hold positions of market power in these and/or closely related markets. We face competition from these
companies, other established companies and potential new entrants. Technological advances may increase
competition or alter the competitive dynamics of markets in which we operate. For example, we face increasing
competition from video services provided by, or over the networks of, the incumbent telecommunications
operators and other service providers. As the availability and speed of broadband internet and mobile
connectivity increases, we also face competition from over-the-top (“OTT”) voice and video call services (such
as Skype, Apple FaceTime, Facebook Messenger, WhatsApp, Google Hangouts and Zoom) and video service
providers utilizing our or our competitors’ high-speed internet connections. In the provision of telephony and
broadband internet services, we are experiencing increasing competition from the incumbent telecommunications
operators and other service providers in the U.K., as well as providers of mobile voice and data. In addition,
continued consolidation within the media industry may permit more competitors to offer “triple-play” bundles of
digital television, fixed-line telephony and broadband internet services, or “quad-play” bundles including mobile
telephony services. Developments in the DSL, as well as investments into FTTx technology by the incumbent
telecommunications operator and alternative providers, in particular the deployment of full fiber networks, have
improved the attractiveness of our competitors’ products and services and strengthened their competitive
position. Developments in and extensive deployment of wireless technologies, such as 5G and fixed wireless
access, are creating additional competitive challenges.

In order to compete effectively, we may be required to reduce the prices we charge for our services (for
example, due to aggressive pricing from our SIM only (“SIMO”) competitors) or increase the value of our
services (for example, by offering increased data with handset bundles) without being able to recoup associated
costs. We may also need to pursue legal and regulatory actions. In addition, some of our competitors offer
services that we are unable to offer. We expect the level and intensity of competition to continue to increase from
both existing competitors and the influx of new market entrants as a result of changes in the regulatory
framework of the industries in which we operate, as well as strategic alliances and cooperative relationships

55


-----

among industry participants. Increased competition could result in increased customer churn, reductions of
customer acquisition rates for some products and services and significant price and promotional competition in
our markets. Additionally, we may see intensified competition in bidding processes for new and existing projects
or customers, and potential losses of business, public sector customers or distributors to other market
participants. In combination with difficult economic environments, these competitive pressures could have a
material adverse effect on our business, cash flows, results of operations and financial condition.

**_Our ability to meet growing customer demand for mobile services and to expand our business depends, in part,_**
**_on the capacity, speed and reliability of our mobile network which in turn depends on our ability to adequately_**
**_manage network capacity and usage levels, successfully implement capacity expansion and yield management_**
**_strategies, and acquire additional spectrum._**

We currently one of two operators with the least amount of spectrum of any mobile network operator
(“MNO”) in the U.K. alongside Three. Recent technological advances and changes in customer behavior and
demands, including the increasing prevalence of smartphones and tablets and the use of data-intensive
applications on such devices (such as streaming of high-definition video and making video calls), have resulted
in substantial growth in mobile data volumes. Total mobile data volumes in the U.K. have grown sharply in
