**USE OF PROCEEDS**

The net proceeds from the offering of the Notes are expected to be £1,124.0 million (equivalent) (after
deducting an estimated £6.2 million (equivalent) of commissions and expenses associated with the offering of the
Notes).

On the Issue Date, the net proceeds from the offering of the Notes, together with certain amounts received
under the New Finco Facility Fee Letters, will be used by the Issuer to fund the New Finco Loans to the New
VM Credit Facility Borrower pursuant to the VM Credit Facility. The gross proceeds of the New Finco Loans
will be used, together with existing cash and cash equivalents, to repay £1,124 million aggregate principal
amount outstanding under Facility P under the VM Credit Facility (the “Facility P Repayment”).

In accordance with the VMED O2 Green Bond Framework, the Joint Venture intends to use an amount
equal to the net proceeds of the Notes to finance and/or refinance new and/or existing VM Eligible Green
Projects and to pay fees and expenses in relation thereto. Accordingly, on June 14, 2021, Sustainalytics, a
provider of environmental, social and governance (“ESG”) research and analysis, evaluated the VMED O2
Green Bond Framework and certified that it aligns with the 2021 Green Bond Principles and provided views on
the robustness and credibility of the VMED O2 Green Bond Framework (which views are intended to inform
investors in general, and not for a specific investor). See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and the
_Structure—The Notes may not be a suitable investment for all investors seeking exposure to “green” assets” and_
“Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and the Structure—Investors may have limited remedies if we fail to
_allocate an amount equal to the net proceeds from the offering of the Notes to finance and/or refinance new and/_
_or existing VM Eligible Green Projects or to satisfy related reporting requirements and other undertakings”._

**VMED O2 Green Bond Framework**

To support Virgin Media’s Meaningful Connections Plan, the Joint Venture has established a Green Bond
Framework (the “VMED O2 Green Bond Framework”), under which the Joint Venture can issue green bonds
to finance or refinance projects, enabling the group to meet its environmental objectives. The VMED O2 Green
Bond Framework outlines the Joint Venture’s commitments with respect to any green bonds that will be issued.
The VMED O2 Green Bond Framework is aligned with the 2021 Green Bond Principles that recommend
transparency and disclosure, and promote integrity in the development of the green bond market. The SecondParty Opinion and the VMED O2 Green Bond Framework will be publicly available on our website
(www.virginmediao2.co.uk). Please note that such information and materials found on, or accessible through, our
website are not part of this offering memorandum and are not incorporated by reference herein.

The VMED O2 Green Bond Framework is presented through the following key pillars:

    - Use of Proceeds;

    - Process for Project Evaluation and Selection;

    - Management of Proceeds;

    - Reporting; and

    - External Review.

**_Use of proceeds_**

The Joint Venture will finance eligible green projects of Virgin Media (“VM Eligible Green Projects”) that
support the transition to a net zero carbon and zero waste future for its U.K. operations. Refinancing of VM
Eligible Green Projects will have a look-back period of no longer than 36 months from the time of issuance. The
net proceeds or an amount equal to the net proceeds raised through any green bonds will be allocated to the
financing and refinancing of VM Eligible Green Projects. VM Eligible Green Projects as defined in the VMED
O2 Green Bond Framework are projects that address Energy Efficiency, Renewable Energy, Clean Transport and
Circular Economy Adapted Products.

**_Process for Project Evaluation and Selection_**

Projects financed or refinanced through the net proceeds or an amount equal to the net proceeds of any
green bond issued under the VMED O2 Green Bond Framework will be evaluated and selected based on
compliance with the eligibility criteria set by the VMED O2 Green Bond Framework.

Virgin Media has established a “Better for the Planet” steering committee (the “Better for the Planet
**Committee”) which will oversee the selection of VM Eligible Green Projects in accordance with the eligibility**

96


-----

criteria described above. The Better for the Planet Committee is comprised of senior representatives from
relevant operational teams and supported by the Sustainability and Finance teams. It is also chaired by the Chief
Technology and Information Officer, previously a member of the Virgin Media Executive Committee and now a
member of the Joint Venture Leadership Team.

**_Management of Proceeds_**

The net proceeds or an amount equal to the net proceeds of any green bond raised under the VMED O2
Green Bond Framework will be allocated by the Joint Venture to finance or refinance VM Eligible Green
Projects, as per the VMED O2 Green Bond Framework’s eligibility criteria and the project selection process
outlined above. Such allocation will be reflected in the Joint Venture’s internal records by the use of a green
bond register. The Joint Venture intends to allocate the net proceeds or an amount equal to the net proceeds of a
green bond to finance or refinance VM Eligible Green Projects within three years from the date of issuance of
such applicable green bond. Any portion of the net proceeds or an amount equal to the net proceeds of a green
bond that has not been allocated to VM Eligible Green Projects will be managed in accordance with the Joint
Venture’s standard liquidity management practices.

**_Reporting_**

The Joint Venture will make available reports covering allocation of the net proceeds or an amount equal to
the net proceeds to the VM Eligible Green Projects and reports on the impact of the VM Eligible Green Projects.
The reporting will be made available within one year from the issuance of any green bonds and will be updated
annually until full allocation of the green bond net proceeds or an amount equal to the net proceeds. The Initial
Purchasers do not undertake to review or monitor such reports during the life of the Notes or to advise any
investor or potential purchaser in the Notes of any information coming to the attention of any Initial Purchaser.
The reporting will be on an aggregate basis, at the level of the project portfolio. It will include:

_Allocation reporting_

    - Total amount allocated to the VM Eligible Green Projects Portfolio, reported by project category

    - Share of net proceeds or an amount equal to the net proceeds used for financing vs. refinancing

    - Balance of unallocated proceeds

The Joint Venture intends to engage their external auditor to review the reporting of the allocation of
proceeds towards VM Eligible Green Projects.

_Impact reporting_

On a best effort basis, the Joint Venture intends to report on the environmental impacts achieved by VM
Eligible Green Projects funded by the net proceeds. The impact reporting will include a description of VM
Eligible Green Projects and impact metrics measured at the level of the overall business.

**_External Review_**

The Issuer has engaged an external verifier, Sustainalytics, to review the VMED O2 Green Bond
Framework. On June 14, 2021, Sustainalytics provided an independent Second Party Opinion on the VMED O2
Green Bond Framework’s environmental credentials and its alignment with the 2021 Green Bond Principles.

On an annual basis, an external auditor will review the allocation of proceeds towards VM Eligible Green
Projects provided in the annual allocation report.

**MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF**
**OPERATIONS OF THE O2 GROUP**

_The following discussion should be read together with the O2 Annual Consolidated Financial Statements_
_and the O2 Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements, as well as with the “Presentation of_
_Financial and Other Information”, “Summary Financial and Operating Data of the O2 Group”, “Business of_
_the O2 Group”, and “Unaudited Condensed Pro Forma Combined Financial Statements of JV Holdco” sections_
_included elsewhere in this offering memorandum._

The following discussion contains certain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties.
O2 Holdings’ actual results could differ materially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements.
Factors that could cause or contribute to such differences include those discussed below and elsewhere in this
offering memorandum, particularly in the sections entitled “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors”.

**Overview**

The O2 Group is a leading telecommunications provider and the largest mobile services providers in the
U.K (in terms of number of subscribers, according to management estimates) as of March 31, 2021, and the
second largest U.K. mobile operator in terms of mobile revenue in 2020 (including giffgaff) (source: Analysys
Mason). The O2 Group performs its activities through its operating subsidiaries in the U.K. which are:

    - Telefonica UK Limited, a MNO trading in the U.K. under the brand name “O2”, providing mobile
telecommunications and related services to a growing customer base; and

    - giffgaff Limited (“giffgaff”), a MVNO operating on the O2 network.

The principal activity of the O2 Group is the operation of a cellular communications network using
spectrum held under licenses granted to provide mobile communications services to its customers under the “O2”
and “giffgaff” brands.

The O2 Group has only one reportable segment, which is the mobile telecommunications business in the
U.K. The mobile telecommunications segment derives revenue from the operation of a cellular communications
network, and the sale of mobile and data services to the O2 Group’s customer base.

For a more detailed description of the business of the O2 Group, see “Business of the O2 Group” included
elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

**Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of the O2 Group’s Financial Condition and Results of**
**Operations**

The following factors affect the comparability of the O2 Group’s results of operations in the periods under
review:

**_IFRS 16 (Leases)_**

On January 1, 2019, IFRS 16 (Leases) (“IFRS 16”) became effective. Its implementation had a material
impact on the consolidated results of the O2 Group. The impact of IFRS 16 for the year ended December 31,
2019, was an increase of £707 million in total assets and total liabilities. In addition, as a result of the adoption of
IFRS 16, most lease expenses that under the prior accounting standard affected operating expenses now affect
depreciation and amortization or net financial costs, resulting in higher OIBDA and higher operating profit, and
are not directly comparable with lease expenses in periods prior to the adoption of IFRS 16. The adoption of
IFRS 16 had no impact on revenue growth, while it had a 12.0% positive impact on OIBDA for the year ended
December 31, 2019, compared with the year ended December 31, 2018.

For certain explanations in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results
_of Operations of the O2 Group”, the impact of the adoption of IFRS 16 has been excluded in order to facilitate_
year-on-year comparison. The O2 Group believes that variations excluding the impact of IFRS 16 provide
valuable supplemental information regarding the O2 Group’s results of operations. However, these variations
may differ from similarly titled measures used by other companies, are not intended to be a substitute for changes
in reported amounts presented in conformity with IFRS and should not be viewed in isolation.

101


-----

For additional information on the impact of IFRS 16, see note 2 to the O2 Annual Consolidated Financial
Statements for the year ended December 31, 2019.

**Factors Affecting the O2 Group’s Historical and Future Results of Operations**

**_Operating environment_**

The O2 Group’s results of operations are dependent, to a large extent, on the level of demand for its services
in the market in which the O2 Group operates. Traditionally, demand for services is affected by the performance
of the mobile telecommunications market in the U.K. and its economy, particularly household private
consumption, but also gross domestic product, inflation, or consumer price index, external accounts and
unemployment rates. The recent COVID-19 pandemic, however, could significantly affect demand for the O2
Group’s services.

**_COVID-19_**

During the COVID-19 pandemic, telecommunications has played a critical role keeping people connected.
As a result, the O2 Group has maximized some elements of its network capacity, enabling essential connectivity,
to support the U.K.’s productivity. The O2 Group’s network has been carrying up to 48% additional voice traffic
at the busiest point of the day. At its peak, the increase was comparable to six years of regular year- on-year
growth. The O2 Group doubled the capacity of its voice network, through reconfiguration of network equipment
in certain areas, to accommodate this increase and continues to actively monitor the network to maintain voice
and data connectivity for all customers.

The O2 Group has also followed U.K. Government advice to help protect its employees and customers. The
O2 Group immediately implemented business continuity plans to allow office-based employees to work from
home and closed all retail locations after trading on March 23, 2020, ahead of the first national lockdown
announcement by the U.K. Government. Since the initial lockdown period, the O2 Group has implemented a
work from home policy where possible to do so ensuring the safety and welfare of its employees and the ability
to continue to meet the needs of customers. In addition, the O2 Group introduced a range of temporary measures
to assist its employees (including retail employees), including the protection of base pay for all employees, paid
leave for vulnerable employees and for those in self-isolation, or with caring responsibilities who are unable to
work from home.

The O2 Group worked closely with the government to provide assistance to the U.K. National Health
Services (“NHS”) workers, charities and our customers by providing 25% discount on tariffs and free data for
NHS workers, unlimited free calls for contract customers, suspended roaming charges, support for vulnerable
customers and zero-rating access to support and charity websites. The O2 Group also provided access to the O2
Arena to the NHS free of charge as a training facility for staff at the London NHS Nightingale hospital and
delivered connectivity to over 1,600 NHS vaccine centres.

Following the phased easing of lockdown restrictions, the O2 Group remains committed to ensuring the
continuing safety of its employees and customers and have re-engineered its retail locations, practices and
procedures to align with the government guidelines for social distancing. The O2 Group’s corporate offices and
sites have also re-opened in line with Governmental and local health and safety guidelines. The O2 Group is
mindful of the economic pressure and impact on profitability growth and is committed to helping the U.K. return
to normalcy by supporting customers and businesses.

**_Foreign exchange rates_**

The O2 Group’s functional and presentation currency is the pound sterling, which is the currency of the
primary economic environment in which the O2 Group operates. The O2 Group is exposed to non-material
transactional foreign exchange risks arising from various currency movements, primarily with respect to the euro
and U.S. dollar that could affect its results and financial position.

To minimize the effect of foreign exchange fluctuations, the O2 Group utilizes hedging instruments made
available to them by the Telefónica Group and has established a set of policies, including the use of derivatives,
primarily exchange rates hedging instruments. The O2 Group utilizes foreign exchange rate hedging instruments
to hedge foreign exchange rate exposure principally in respect of euro and U.S. dollar payments with regard to
roaming agreements and not for speculative purposes.

102


-----

**_Taxation_**

The O2 Group is subject to taxation. The charge for tax is based on the results for the period as adjusted for
items which are non-assessable or disallowed.

As of March 31, 2021, deferred tax assets amounted to £4 million and deferred tax liabilities amounted to
£70 million. As of December 31, 2020, 2019, and 2018 deferred tax assets amounted to £4 million, £7 million
and zero, respectively, while deferred tax liabilities amounted to £58 million, £52 million and £37 million,
respectively.

Deferred tax assets are offset against deferred tax liabilities where there is a legally enforceable right of
offset and they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority on either the same taxable entity or
different entities which intend to settle current tax assets and liabilities on a net basis.

**_Revenue_**

Revenue, which excludes value added tax and other sales taxes, comprises mobile business, consisting of
mobiles revenues and handset revenues, and fixed business (each as described in more detail below). Mobile and
fixed revenues may be sold separately or bundled in promotional packages. Total package revenues are allocated
among the identified performance obligations based on their respective standalone selling prices.

    - **_Mobile business revenues include mobile business revenues and handset revenues and refer to_**
revenues derived from telecommunications services provided to the customers through the O2 Group’s
mobile voice and data services, both in the prepaid and postpaid segment. Mobile business revenue
includes revenue earned for usage of the O2 Group’s wireless network for voice, text message and data
transmission by the O2 Group’s customers, subscription fees (including those earned from the O2
Group’s MVNO partners), inbound roaming (earned from foreign mobile operators whose customers
roam onto the O2 Group’s network), outbound roaming (earned from the O2 Group’s customers
roaming outside their domestic coverage area) and interconnect revenue (earned from other
telecommunication operators whose customers terminate calls on the O2 Group’s network). Handset
revenue principally consists of revenue from the sale of mobile devices, including smartphones and
other mobile handsets sold through the O2 Group’s direct distribution channels under the “O2 Refresh”
proposition (where hardware is recognized as a separate performance obligation and deliverable to
airtime), as well as the sale of tablets, smart-tech (for example, smart watches and fitness devices) and
accessories (for example, mobile phone cases, screen protectors, chargers, cables, portable batteries,
headphones and speakers). Handset revenue is recognized when the products are delivered to the
customer. Handset billing will typically include an upfront amount and the remaining payments are
spread over the contract term. Where the implied financing element of these payments is significant
when compared with the other performance obligations in the contract, a portion of the revenue is
allocated to significant financing and is charged to the profit and loss statement as interest costs over
the term of the contract. Mobile business revenues also includes the O2 Group’s Smart Metering
Implementation Program (“SMIP”) contract.

    - **_Fixed business revenues include information and communication technology revenues provided to_**
business customers and associated with the provision of complete connectivity, whether through fixedline, Wi-Fi or mobile technology. Solutions (apps, tools and services) are provided encompassing
connectivity, productivity and security.

**_Average Revenue per User (“O2 ARPU”)_**

Average revenue per user for the O2 Group is calculated as total revenue less inbound roaming revenue,
MVNO revenue, wholesale discounts, hardware revenue and non-mobile revenue divided by the average of the
monthly average accesses for the period.

**_OIBDA and OIBDA Margin_**

OIBDA is calculated by excluding depreciation and amortization from operating profit. OIBDA Margin is
OIBDA calculated as a percentage of revenue. See “—Special Note Regarding Non-IFRS Measures”.

**_Capital expenditures (“CapEx”)_**

CapEx includes spectrum acquisitions (additions of spectrum included in intangible assets), additions to
property, plant and equipment and intangible assets.

**_OIBDA-CapEx and OIBDA – CapEx Margin_**

OIBDA-CapEx is calculated as OIBDA minus CapEx. OIBDA-CapEx Margin is OIBDA-CapEx calculated
as a percentage of revenue. See “—Special Note Regarding Non-IFRS Measures”.

104


-----

**_Mobile accesses_**

Mobile accesses include accesses to the mobile network for voice and/or data services (including
connectivity). Mobile accesses are divided into three different categories: Prepaid accesses, Contract accesses
and, since March 2020, Internet of Things (“IoT”) accesses. IoT accesses for the three-month period ended
March 31, 2021 and the comparative period for 2020 and for the year ended December 31, 2020, are reported
separately from Contract accesses. For the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2018, IoT accesses are reported
within Contract accesses.

**_Wholesale accesses_**

Wholesale accesses are provided by the O2 Group directly to third parties who then deliver services over
such accesses to both consumer and corporate clients.

**_Total accesses_**

Total accesses are the number of connections on the O2 network, including giffgaff, Tesco Mobile Limited
(“Tesco Mobile”), Sky Mobile, Lycamobile and other MVNO partners.

**Special Note Regarding Non-IFRS Measures**

The O2 Group’s management believes that, in addition to the financial information expressly defined under
IFRS, there are measures that provide information useful to assess the O2 Group’s performance. These measures
should not be viewed in isolation or as a substitute for the measures presented according to IFRS. See
“Presentation of Financial and Other Information”.

The following non-IFRS alternative performance measures of the O2 Group are presented in this offering
memorandum: OIBDA, OIBDA Margin, CapEx, OIBDA-CapEx, OIBDA-CapEx Margin and Net debt. Such
measures are presented in order to show the underlying business performance and to enhance comparability
between reporting periods. By facilitating comparisons of relative performance, the measures aid management to
detect and evaluate trends, to forecast operating and financial performance and to compare actual performance to
forecast expectations. The O2 Group uses these measures as internal measures to evaluate and compare its
performance. For these reasons, the O2 Group believes measures based on OIBDA and other non-financial
measures are regularly used by investors as a means of comparing companies in its industry.

However, the non-IFRS alternative performance measures of the O2 Group presented in this offering
memorandum are not defined under IFRS, and different companies and analysts may calculate them differently,
thus comparisons among companies on this basis should be made carefully. They are not measures of
performance under IFRS and have not been audited or reviewed, should not be considered in isolation, do not
represent the O2 Group’s revenue, margins, results of operations or cash flow for the periods indicated and
should not be regarded as alternatives to revenue, cash flow or profit for the period or other measures of
performance as defined by IFRS.

The non-IFRS alternative performance measures of the O2 Group presented in this offering memorandum
include figures derived from the O2 Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements and the O2 Annual
Consolidated Financial Statements through aggregation, subtraction or division.

The comparability of these measures throughout the periods under review is also affected by the impact of
adopting IFRS 16 in 2019. See “—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of the O2 Group’s Financial
_Condition and Results of Operations”._

**_Definitions and Reconciliations_**

_OIBDA, OIBDA Margin, OIBDA-CapEx and OIBDA-CapEx Margin_

The O2 Group measures its performance by the OIBDA, OIBDA Margin, OIBDA-CapEx and OIBDACapEx Margin and uses these metrics to make decisions about allocating resources to evaluate its financial
performance and to establish operating and strategic targets of O2 Group companies. OIBDA is a commonly
reported measure and is widely used among analysts, investors and other stakeholders in the telecommunications
industry.

105


-----

OIBDA is calculated by excluding depreciation and amortization from operating profit. OIBDA Margin is
OIBDA calculated as a percentage of revenue. However, OIBDA is not a measure expressly defined under IFRS
and therefore it may not be comparable to similar indicators used by other companies. OIBDA should not be
considered as a substitute for operating profit.

The O2 Group believes that it is important to consider CapEx, together with OIBDA in order to have a more
complete measure of the performance of its telecommunications businesses. The O2 Group believes that
considering CapEx together with OIBDA provides useful information regarding both its performance during the
year as well as the investments the O2 Group made during such year in order to support its business going
forward. Therefore, the O2 Group uses these measures internally to track the performance of its business, to
establish operating and strategic targets of the businesses of the O2 Group and in its internal budgeting process.

In addition, the O2 Group believes that these measures provide useful information to investors and other
stakeholders to allow them to better compare performance across telecommunications companies with business
models that differ based on whether they obtain network access, IT and other infrastructure services by paying
fees that would be reflected in OIBDA through the development of owned networks and infrastructures that
would be reflected in CapEx. Furthermore, similar metrics are reported externally by other telecommunications
companies, and investors and analysts often track and compare these measures across different
telecommunications companies.

_Net debt_

The O2 Group believes that Net debt is meaningful for investors and analysts because it provides solvency

leverage ratios. However, Net debt should not be considered as a substitute for total borrowings as presented in
the consolidated statement of financial position of the O2 Group.

**Description of Key Income Statement Items**

The following provides a description of the key income statement items of the O2 Group for the periods
presented in this offering memorandum.

**_Revenue_**

The O2 Group’s revenues are derived from providing telecommunications services and the sale of mobile
devices. See “—Key Performance Indicators of the O2 Group—Revenue”.

**_Operating costs_**

Operating costs principally include:

    - _Supplies, which principally consist of interconnection and roaming costs incurred in connecting the O2_
Group’s customers to other mobile networks, costs associated with hardware procurement, indirect
distribution channel sales costs and costs associated with providing connectivity to consumer and
business customers.

    - _Personnel expenses, which comprise wages and salaries and related direct employment costs for_
permanent employees, adjusted for own work capitalized.

    - _Depreciation, which is provided on property, plant and equipment from the date the asset is available_
for use over its estimated useful life on a straight-line basis and is provided on freehold land or assets
in the course of construction.

    - _Amortization, which is similarly provided on certain intangible assets, principally spectrum licenses_
and software, over their estimated useful lives on a straight-line basis.

    - _Management fees, which include payables to other Telefónica Group companies outside of the O2_
Group

    - _Other expenses, which principally consist of commissions paid to dealers, network and non-network_
accommodation costs in relation to the O2 Group’s properties, network maintenance costs, customer
service costs, IT and system support costs, marketing costs (comprising advertising, promotion,
sponsorship and communication) and bad debt expenses.

**_Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets_**

Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets include impairment losses on trade receivables and
contract assets.

**_Share of profit of Joint Ventures_**

The O2 Group holds a 50% interest in Tesco Mobile, a mobile network operator, which is accounted for
using the equity method. The share of profit of joint venture reflects the O2 Group’s share of the results of
operations of Tesco Mobile.

**_Financial income and costs_**

Finance income consists mainly of interest income from banks on the O2 Group deposits, dividends from
investments and income deriving from hedging instruments and other financial income. Financial costs mainly
include interest expense on bank borrowing and financial debts, losses derived from hedging instruments, interest
expenses on leases liabilities over the lease term and other financial costs.

107


-----

**_Taxation expense_**

Corporate income tax consists of current income taxes, changes in deferred tax assets and deferred tax
liabilities calculated on profit or loss before tax, which is affected by temporary and/or permanent corporate tax
changes implemented by applicable laws.

**Revenue amounted to £1,356 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2021, a decrease of 9.5%**
compared to the three-month period ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was mainly driven by stores being
closed for the first three months of the year in 2021 due to COVID-19, compared to only two weeks of closure
during the first quarter of 2020, negatively affecting handset sales, although this was partially offset by an
increase in online trading.

    - **Mobile business revenue amounted to £1,307 million for the three-month period ended March 31,**
2021, compared to £1,445 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2020, a decrease of
9.6%. This decrease was primarily due to the closure of stores during the three months ended
March 31, 2021 compared to only two weeks of closure during the three months ended March 31, 2020
due to COVID-19 lockdowns. This negatively affected handset sales, but was, however, partially offset
by an increase in online trading. Handset revenue amounted to £323 million for the three-month period
ended March 31, 2021, compared to £369 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2020, a
decrease of 12.5%. This decrease was primarily due to COVID-19 related store closures during the
three months ended March 31, 2021 mentioned above.

    - **Fixed business revenue amounted to £49 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2021,**
compared to £53 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2021, a decrease of 7.5%. This
decrease was primarily due to This decrease was primarily due to COVID-19 related store closures
during the three months ended March 31, 2021 mentioned above.

**Operating costs amounted to £1,110 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2021, compared**
to £1,276 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2020, a decrease of 13.0%. This decrease was
mainly a result of strong cost control and enhanced direct trading resulting in less commissions payable to thirdparties.

**Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets amounted to £30 million for the three-month**
period ended March 31, 2021, compared to £39 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2020, a
decrease of 23.1%. This decrease was mainly driven by reduced impairment losses on trade receivables and
contract assets.

**Revenue amounted to £6,235 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to £6,007 million**
for the year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of 3.8%. This increase was mainly driven by online channel
sales growth as well as increased higher-value handset revenue due to the full year impact of the O2 Group’s
“Custom Plans”, which enable customers to spread the cost of their phones over different terms, flex their data up
and down and upgrade whenever they like. “Custom Plans” was launched in September 2018. In addition, there
was continued growth in SMIP, as well as increased MVNO revenue over the period. These increases were
partially offset by a reduction in roaming revenue over the period.

    - **Mobile business revenue amounted to £6,044 million for the year ended December 31, 2019,**
compared to £5,816 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of 3.9%. This increase
was mainly due to continued MVNO growth and associated revenue increases. Handset revenue
amounted to £1,575 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to £1,374 million for the
year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of 14.6%. This increase was due to increasing handset
revenues resulting from the full year impact of the O2 Group’s “Custom Plans” (as described above)
which launched in September 2018 and continued growth from SMIP.

    - **Fixed business revenue were stable year on year and amounted to £191.4 million for the year ended**
December 31, 2019, compared to £191.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of
0.2%.

**Operating costs amounted to £5,262 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to**
£5,134 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of 2.5%. This increase was mainly due to the
increase in right of use asset depreciation due to the first application of IFRS 16 from January 1, 2019, partially
offset by a reduction in operating lease rentals. Excluding the impact of IFRS 16, operating costs amounted to
£5,272 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of 2.7% compared to the year ended
December 31, 2018, mainly due to the increase in property, plant and equipment depreciation due and to higher
Annual License Fee payments related to spectrum license costs for telecommunication activities for 3G, 4G and
5G (3.4GHz ) services provided since February 2019 (during the year ended December 31, 2019 amortization of
the 5G (3.4Ghz) spectrum started from October when the license was placed in service), partially offset by a
reduction in costs associated with reduced roaming.

**Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets amounted to £149 million for the year ended**
December 31, 2019 compared to £89 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of 67.4%. This
increase was mainly due to a £49 million increase related to an increase in the cost of selling rate of receivables
related to the “O2 Refresh” proposition.

**OIBDA amounted to £1,805 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to £1,605 million for**
the year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of 12.5%. Excluding the impact of IFRS 16, OIBDA amounted to
£1,613 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to £1,605 million for the year ended
December 31, 2018, an increase of 0.5% mainly due to the increase in the O2 Group’s revenue, which was
proportionally higher than the related increase in operating costs.

December 31, 2019, compared to 26.7% for the year ended December 31, 2018.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

The O2 Group’s main sources of liquidity are cash generated from operations (see “—Consolidated
_Statement of Cash Flows”), funds from financings related parties (ultimately from the Telefónica Group in the_
form of loans or contributions), proceeds in the form of distributions or loans from our subsidiaries and capital
contributions. The O2 Group’s objectives when managing capital are to safeguard the O2 Group’s ability to
continue to operate as a going concern, to maintain optimal capital structure commensurate with risk and return
and to reduce the cost of capital.

The O2 Group’s principal liquidity and capital resources requirements consist of the following:

    - costs and expenses relating to the operation of the business, including taxation expenses;

    - capital expenditures, which are mainly intended to improve the O2 Group’s network;

    - acquisitions of property, plant and equipment, intangible assets and spectrum;

    - intra-group loan service requirements relating to the existing and future loan;

    - payments of dividends and shareholder remuneration;

    - acquisitions and investment opportunities;

    - distributions or loans to giffgaff, Tesco Mobile or other subsidiaries of the O2 Group; and

    - any other liquidity requirements that may arise from time to time.

Cash flows from operations are the primary source of cash funding for existing operations, capital
expenditures, investments, licenses, interest obligations and principal payments, as well as capital increases. The
O2 Group general financial policy consists in managing its liquidity to ensure that funds required for future
obligations are available from cash or from the sources listed above to settle liabilities as they become due.

For the amortization schedule of current and non-current financial liabilities, see “—Financing” below.

**_Borrowings_**

Non-current borrowings remained at £964 million as of March 31, 2021, compared to £964 million as of
December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018. Current borrowings increased to £448 million as of March 31, 2021. The
total amount of borrowings for the period corresponds to amounts owed to other related parties under intra-group
loans or facilities with Telfin Ireland and Telfisa Global BV (each a Telefónica Group company) (the “Intra**Group Loans”).**

As of March 31, 2021, the main features of the Intra-Group Loans were as follows:

    - a facility to assist with the acquisition of 20 MHz of paired 700 MHz FDD spectrum and 40 MHz of
3.6 - 3.8 GHz spectrum which has an interest rate based on LIBOR plus 45 basis points up until
June 30, 2021. The maturity date of this loan is June 30, 2021.

    - a loan to assist with the acquisition of 800MHz 4G spectrum which had an interest rate based on
LIBOR plus 272 basis points up until June 30, 2018 and LIBOR plus 105 basis points from July 1,
2018 and is calculated on a quarterly basis. The maturity date of this loan is June 30, 2023.

    - a loan to assist with the acquisition of 2.3GHz 4G and 3.4GHz 5G spectrum which has an interest rate
based on LIBOR plus 90 basis points and is calculated on a quarterly basis. The maturity date of this
loan is June 30, 2022.

The Intra-Group Loans were repaid in connection with the consummation of the Joint Venture Transactions.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure about Market Risk**

The O2 Group’s operations expose it to a variety of financial risks including foreign currency risk, interest
rate risk, liquidity risk and credit risk. The principal market financial risks of the O2 Group and how the O2
Group manages these risks are discussed below.

**_Foreign currency risk_**

The O2 Group operates mainly in the U.K. but is exposed to transactional foreign exchange risks arising
from various currency movements, primarily with respect to the euro and U.S. dollar that can affect its results
and financial position. The O2 Group believes that the impact of any reasonable change in foreign exchange rates
would not have a significant impact on the results of the O2 Group.

The O2 Group also has a small amount of transactional foreign currency risk exposure. Such exposure arises
from revenues and purchases by an operating unit that is in currencies other than the unit’s functional currency.
Significant exposures are managed through the use of foreign exchange contracts and the Telefónica Group
managing positions on a Telefónica Group wide basis.

**_Interest rate risk_**

Interest rate risk is the risk that fair value or future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate
because of changes in market interest rates.

The O2 Group’s interest rate risk arises primarily from the effects of movements in interest rates on the
value of the O2 Group’s long-term borrowings and interest received on cash and cash equivalents. The O2
Group’s long-term borrowings and other financial assets are at fixed interest rates. The majority of the O2
Group’s cash and cash equivalents are deposited with a central Telefónica Group company that pays interest at
variable market rates.

The O2 Group believes that the impact of any reasonable change in interest rates would not have a
significant impact on the result of the O2 Group for the year.

**_Liquidity risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that an entity will encounter difficulty in meeting its obligations associated with
financial liabilities as they fall due.

Management of the O2 Group’s liquidity risk is achieved mostly through being a part of the larger
Telefónica Group, which operates Telefónica Group wide policies in this area. The O2 Group holds financial
assets primarily in short-term deposits with a central Telefónica Group company that are readily convertible to
known amounts of cash. These measures help keep liquidity risk low.

**_Credit risk_**

Credit risk is the risk that a counterparty will not meet its obligation under a financial instrument or
customer contract, leading to a financial loss.

The O2 Group’s principal credit risks are attributable to its trade receivables and contract assets. Trade
receivables as presented in the statement of financial position are net of provision for doubtful debts, estimated
by the O2 Group’s management based on prior experience and their assessment of the current economic
environment. Management has a credit policy in place and the exposure to credit risk is monitored on an ongoing
basis. At the statement of financial position date there were no significant concentrations of credit risk, with
exposure spread over a large number of counterparties and customers. The maximum exposure to credit risk is
represented by the carrying amount of each financial asset in the statement of financial position. The O2 Group
does not require collateral in respect of financial assets.

**Critical Accounting Policies**

The O2 Annual Consolidated Financial Statements and the O2 Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial
Statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRS.

Critical accounting policies are those that are most important to the portrayal of the O2 Group’s financial
condition, results of operations and cash flows, and require management to make difficult, subjective or complex
judgments, assumptions and estimates about matters that are inherently uncertain or where judgments,
assumptions and estimates are significant. Management bases its estimates on historical experience and other
assumptions that it believes are reasonable based upon information available to us at the time that these
judgments, assumptions and estimates are made. The O2 Group continually evaluates its judgments, estimates
and assumptions. Its actual results may differ from the judgments, assumptions and estimates made by the
management. To the extent that there are material differences between these judgments, assumptions and
estimates (on the one hand) and actual results (on the other hand), its future financial statement presentation,
financial condition, results of operation and cash flows may be affected. In order to provide an understanding
regarding the manner in which the management forms its judgments about future events, including the variables
underlying the judgments, estimates and assumptions, the O2 Group summarizes its main critical accounting
policies below relating to:

    - property, plant and equipment, intangible assets and goodwill;

    - deferred income taxes.

    - provisions;

    - revenue recognition; and

    - leases (IFRS 16).

See note 3 to the O2 Annual Consolidated Financial Statements and note 3 to the O2 Interim Condensed
Consolidated Financial Statements for further information regarding the O2 Group’s accounting policies.

**_Property, plant and equipment, intangible assets and goodwill_**

_Property, plant and equipment_

The accounting treatment of investments in property, plant and equipment and intangible assets entails the
use of estimates to determine the useful life for depreciation and amortization purposes. The O2 Group believes
that the estimates it makes to determine an asset’s useful life are “critical accounting estimates” because they
require the management to make estimates about technological evolution and competitive uses of assets.

Property, plant and equipment and intangible assets with definite useful lives are depreciated or amortized
on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives. Intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are not
amortized, but are, instead, subject to an impairment test on a yearly basis and whenever there is an indication
that such assets may be impaired. When the O2 Group estimates useful lives, various factors are considered
including expected technological obsolescence and the expected period of use of the asset. Management regularly
reviews these asset lives and change them as necessary to reflect the estimated current remaining lives in light of
technological changes, future economic utilization and physical condition of the assets concerned. A significant
change in asset lives can have a significant impact on depreciation and amortization charges for the period.

The decision to recognize an impairment loss involves developing estimates that include, among others, an
analysis of the causes of the potential impairment, its timing and expected amount, which requires the estimation
of future cash flows, discount rates and the fair value of the assets. Specifically, management shall make certain
assumptions in respect of uncertain matters, such as growth in revenues, changes in market prices, operating
margins, and technology developments and obsolescence, discontinuance of services and other changes in
circumstances that indicate the need to perform an impairment test. The determination of whether the impairment
of these assets is necessary involves the use of estimates that includes, but is not limited to, the analysis of the
cause of potential impairment in value, the timing of such potential impairment and an estimate of the amount of
the impairment. The O2 Group considers technological obsolescence, discontinuance of services and other
changes in circumstances as indications of the need to perform an impairment test.

118


-----

Goodwill arises when the cost of a business combination exceeds the acquirer’s interest in the net fair value
of the identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed at the acquisition date. Goodwill is not amortized, but
is, instead, subject to an impairment test on a yearly basis and whenever there is an indication that the goodwill
may be impaired.

Non-scheduled write-downs of goodwill are made when an impairment in the carrying amount of goodwill
occurs. The O2 Group reviews, on a regular basis, the performance of its cash-generating units. The O2 Group
compares the carrying amount of the cash-generating unit to which the goodwill has been allocated with its
recoverable amount. The determination of the recoverable amount of the cash-generating unit involves extensive
use of estimates and significant management judgment is involved. Methods commonly used by us for valuations
include discounted cash flow methods. Management makes assumptions including, but not limited to, the
discount rate to be applied, future technological evolution and revenue growth rates in calculating expected cash
flow. See note 7 to the O2 Annual Consolidated Financial Statements.

A significant change in the facts and circumstances that the O2 Group relied upon in making its estimates
may have a material impact on its operating results and financial condition.

**_Deferred income taxes_**

The O2 Group assesses the recoverability of deferred tax assets based on estimates of future earnings, and of
all the options available to achieve an outcome, it considers the most efficient one in tax terms within the legal
framework O2 Group is subject to. Such recoverability ultimately depends on its ability to generate taxable
earnings over the period for which the deferred tax assets remain available. Deferred tax liabilities are recognized
for all taxable temporary differences and deferred tax assets are recognized to the extent that it is probable future
taxable profits will be available against which deductible temporary differences can be utilized. This analysis is
based on the estimated schedule for reversing deferred tax liabilities, as well as estimates of taxable earnings,
which are sourced from internal projections that are continuously updated to reflect the latest trends.

The recognition of tax assets and liabilities depends on a series of factors, including estimates as to the
timing and realization of deferred tax assets and the projected tax payment schedule. Actual O2 Group company
income tax receipts and payments could differ from the estimates made by the O2 Group as a result of changes in
tax legislation, the outcome of underway tax proceedings or unforeseen future transactions that could affect tax
balances.

**_Provisions_**

Provisions are recorded when, at the end of the period, the O2 Group has a present obligation as a result of
past events, whose settlement requires an outflow of resources that is considered probable and can be measured
reliably. This obligation may be legal or constructive, arising from, but not limited to, regulation, contracts,
common practice or public commitments, which have created a valid expectation for third parties that the O2
Group will assume certain responsibilities. The amount recorded is the best estimation performed by the
management in respect of the expenditure that will be required to settle the obligations, considering all the
information available at the closing date, including the advice of external experts, such as legal advisors or
consultants.

Should the O2 Group be unable to reliably measure the obligation, no provision would be recorded and
information would then be presented in the notes to the consolidated financial statements. Because of the
inherent uncertainties in this estimation, actual expenditures may be different from the originally estimated
amount recognized.

Given the uncertainties inherent in the estimates used to determine the amount of provisions, actual outflows
of resources may differ from the amounts recognized originally on the basis of the estimates.

**_Revenue recognition_**

Revenue, which excludes value added tax and other sales taxes, comprises mobile business revenue and
fixed business revenues. See “—Key Performance Indicators of the O2 Group—Revenue”.

Under IFRS 15, for bundled packages that combine mobile services and hardware services, the total revenue
is allocated to each performance obligation based on their standalone selling prices in relation to the total

119


-----

consideration of the package and is recognized when (or as) the obligation is satisfied, regardless of whether
there are undelivered items. Consequently, when bundles include a price difference on equipment, the adoption
of these new requirements results in an increase of revenues recognized from the sale of handsets and other
equipment, generally recognized upon delivery to the end customer, offset by a reduction of ongoing service
revenue over subsequent periods. To the extent that the packages are marketed at a price difference, the
difference between the revenue from the sale of equipment and the consideration received from the customer
upfront is recognized as a contract asset on the statement of financial position and amortized over the term of the
contract.

Under IAS 18 Revenue, which was the revenue standard adopted in the year ended December 31, 2017,
prior to the adoption of IFRS 15, the portion of the total consideration that was contingent upon delivery of
undelivered elements was not allocated to delivered elements.

IFRS 15 requires the recognition of an asset for those incremental costs (sales commissions and other thirdparty acquisition costs) directly related to obtaining a contract and that are expected to be recovered. These are
subsequently amortized over the same period as the revenue associated with such asset. Costs to obtain a contract
are expensed when incurred if the O2 Group estimates that their amortization period is one year or less.

**_Leases (IFRS 16)_**

Accounting for rights and obligations as a lessee under a lease contract requires the use of estimations to
determine the lease term in contracts that include extension options or early termination options.

Determining the lease term involves making estimates over the time horizon of the O2 Group’s strategic
planning process with respect to relevant factors such as expected technological progress, possible regulatory
developments, market and competition trends or changes in the business model. The assumptions regarding these
variables involve a significant degree of judgment to the extent that the timing and nature of future changes are
difficult to anticipate.

Due to the uncertainties inherent to these estimates, changes in the assumptions made in respect of uncertain
matters when determining the lease term of a lease contract may have an impact on the amounts of the right of
use assets and lease liabilities recognized on the basis of the estimates made by the O2 Group.

**BUSINESS OF THE O2 GROUP**

**Introduction**

The O2 Group is a leading U.K. MNO whose primary business is providing mobile telecommunications and
related services with approximately 36.6 million mobile accesses (including wholesale mobile accesses) as of
March 31, 2021.

Under its premium O2 brand, the O2 Group offers a comprehensive range of mobile services and products
to consumer and business customers, including mobile voice, messaging and data services, and sales of handsets,
tablets, wearable devices and other hardware. In addition, the O2 Group offers a wide range of value-add services
and products including Wi-Fi services, security services, cloud services, digital payment services, certain fixedline services for businesses and insurance products. The O2 Group has also developed innovative value-add
services and products, including services and products relating to the Internet of Things (“IoT”), insurance, and
big-data and insight services for businesses. Through its digital loyalty program, Priority, the O2 Group offers its
customers a range of exclusive deals and perks.

In addition to its offerings under its premium O2 brand, the O2 Group also seeks to access additional
customer groups through, for example: (i) its wholly-owned MVNO, giffgaff; (ii) its joint venture with Tesco to
operate Tesco Mobile; and (iii) other MVNOs such as Sky Mobile, Lycamobile, Truphone and Manx Telecom.

The O2 Group was the largest MNO in the U.K. mobile telecommunications market in 2020 based on
mobile subscriptions, with an MNO market share of approximately 33.0% (including giffgaff and MVNOs)
(compared to 32.0% in 2019 and 32.1% in 2018). The O2 Group was the second largest MNO in the U.K. mobile
telecommunications market in 2020 based on mobile service revenue, with an MNO market share of
approximately 29.2% (including giffgaff) (compared to 29.9% in 2019 and 2018) (source: Analysys Mason).

As of March 31, 2021, the O2 Group operated 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G mobile networks providing 2G, 3G and
4G voice and data coverage to more than 99% (in at least one band) of the U.K. outdoor population. In the 2021
uSwitch Mobile Awards, O2 won the Best Network for Coverage award (the fourth consecutive year that O2 has
earned this distinction), while giffgaff won the Network of the Year award.

(2) Following the introduction of IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) (“IFRS 15”), the O2
Group no longer reports “Mobile service revenue”, because it no longer believes that “Mobile service
revenue” is an accurate measure of its revenue, as that metric is disproportionately impacted by the
existence of its “O2 Refresh” proposition contracts and ongoing channel strategy. In addition, the O2 Group
believes that the presentation of “Mobile service revenue” is not in line with its competitors in the industry.
(3) Each connection to any of the O2 Group’s telecommunications services is referred to as an “access”. The
O2 Group believes that it is more useful to count the number of accesses a customer has contracted for,
rather than to count only the number of its customers with multiple accesses whether fixed or mobile. As
such, a customer that has a fixed-line telephony service and a mobile service is counted as two accesses.
(4) Prepaid percentage is calculated by dividing the number of prepaid mobile accesses at period end by the
total number of mobile accesses at period end.
(5) Contract percentage is calculated by dividing the number of contract mobile accesses at period end by the
total number of mobile accesses at period end.
(6) Since March 2020, IoT accesses have been reported separately within Mobile accesses and are no longer
reported as part of Contract accesses. As a result, IoT accesses for the three-month period ended March 31,
2021 and the comparative period for 2020 and for the year ended December 31, 2020 reflect this new
reporting. IoT accesses for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2018 are included in total Contract
accesses.

**Products and Services**

The O2 Group offers a wide range of mobile telecommunications and value-add services and products to its
consumer and business customers under its premium O2 brand. The O2 Group’s approach focuses on the needs
of its customers with the aim of maintaining and increasing its large, loyal customer base to drive value.

**_Consumer services and products_**

The O2 Group offers consumers mobile services (including mobile voice, messaging and data services)
through post-pay and pre-pay models, and offers a range of hardware, including wearables and handsets in
connection with the O2 Group’s mobile service offerings as well as stand-alone mobile devices and accessories.
In addition, the O2 Group offers consumers a range of value-add services and products, including a digital
loyalty program, Wi-Fi, security services, cloud services, digital payment services and insurance with the aim of
differentiating the customer experience and increasing customer loyalty and engagement.

_Mobile services_

The O2 Group offers its consumer customers mobile voice, messaging and data services which are supplied,
at present, through the purchase of a SIM card. Customers can purchase a SIM card either on its own (a “SIMO”
mobile service) or together with a handset. Mobile services for both SIMO and handset options are offered under
two payment models: “pay monthly” (a post-pay model) and “pay as you go” (a pre-pay model). “Pay as you go”
customers can purchase a handset paying in full upfront. “Pay monthly” customers have access to the “Custom
Plan” proposition (as part of O2 Refresh), which allows customers to spread the cost of their phones over
different terms, flex their data up or down and upgrade.

The O2 Group also provides data-only mobile broadband services over its network. Customers can purchase
data-only plans together with a tablet device, or as a SIMO service purchasing data access devices separately, for
example a laptop dongle or an in-car Wi-Fi device.

The O2 Group also provides its O2 Family offering with the aim to simplify billing processes and provide
discounts (based on the number of connections registered) and support for families. For each family connection
registered, the primary account holder receives one bill (rather than multiple bills throughout the month).

The O2 Group has also introduced embedded SIM cards (“eSIM”) for smartphones and released a 5G eSIM
in the autumn of 2020. We continue to build on this capability and have plans to develop a fully digital
distribution method for eSIM, removing the need for paper eSIM vouchers.

122


-----

_Hardware sales_

In addition to handsets, tablets and data access devices offered to its mobile customers, the O2 Group offers
a range of stand-alone products, including smart-tech (such as smart watches and fitness devices) and accessories
(such as handset cases, screen protectors, chargers, cables, portable batteries, headphones and speakers).

As part of the O2 Group’s “Like New” offerings, customers are offered a choice of quality-assured
pre-owned handsets. Customers can purchase “Like New” handsets as part of the O2 Group’s “pay monthly” and
“pay as you go” payment models.

O2 Group and non-O2 Group customers can exchange their existing handset through O2 Recycle, a scheme
which allows people to exchange old phones and other gadgets for a price-matched cash payment. Exchanged
devices are processed for re-use, recycling or are disassembled for the re-use of component parts. In 2020, the O2
Group completed 11 years of O2 Recycle and announced that 3.3 million devices had been diverted from
landfills.

**_Business-to-business services and products_**

The O2 Group is one of the major providers of telecommunications services to business customers in the
U.K. The O2 Group offers services to the full range of business customers, from small and medium businesses
(“SMB”) to large national and international enterprise customers and the public sector. The O2 Group offers
mobile, Wi-Fi and fixed-line services, as well as digital services (including unified communication and digital
collaboration services, cloud services, security services and IoT solutions) to its business customer base. The O2
Group has adopted a distinct customer-led, mobile-first approach, offering simple and flexible combinations of
mobile connectivity, handsets and apps to help its SMB customers set up and run their businesses. For its
enterprise and public sector customers, the O2 Group offers a solution-oriented approach focusing on the needs
of the customer and generating measurable business outcomes, such as cost savings and efficiency gains. In
2020, the O2 Group won the Best Business Network Award at the Mobile Industry Awards.

Excluding revenues from the SMIP (as defined herein), the ten largest enterprise customers accounted for
approximately 36% of the total business customer revenue of the O2 Group for the year ended December 31,
2020 and have been with the O2 Group for an average of over 7 years.

_SMB_

The O2 Group offers its SMB customers a competitive mobile service tariff, a wide range of apps providing
digital services and products and fixed-line services including fiber broadband and high-speed internet, with the
aim of helping its business customers’ employees work more efficiently and productively.

The O2 Group offers a growing number of apps to help businesses work more efficiently and productively
by communicating and collaborating from different locations on a variety of devices. The O2 Group has
partnered with large multinational companies to provide their software and apps to its business customers which
allows businesses to securely share and work on content through the cloud. For example, the O2 Group is a
Microsoft Gold Partner and McAfee’s largest Telco reseller in Europe, supplying Microsoft Office 365 and
McAfee’s security services to its business customers.

_Enterprise and multinational customers_

For its enterprise and multinational customers, the O2 Group designs end-to-end solutions tailored to its
customers’ needs and based on a bespoke combination of the O2 Group’s services and products, including
mobile services and connectivity solutions, digital workplace, integrated data networks with mobile and fixedline services, unified communication and digital collaboration services (such as instant messaging, video and
screen sharing), cloud services and security services. The O2 Group offers a fully integrated service for its
enterprise customers through the “O2 Gateway”, which brings together mobile, Wi-Fi and fixed-line services. O2
Gateway enables connectivity using a range of access methods and network types (WAN, Wi-Fi and mobile),
providing enhanced security and resilience with dedicated capacity for business services from communications to
web services. The range of services provided is growing, from voice and cloud services, to applications including
Skype for Business. The fixed-line services include managed WAN, managed LAN, business broadband internet
and high-speed internet. The O2 Gateway service can also be utilised for improved quality of service and
additional resilience to digital communication services such as Microsoft Teams Voice services.

123


-----

Providing additional Digital services beyond voice, connectivity and cloud services using the O2 Group’s
wider Digital Solutions portfolio with products such as IoT smart connect and asset management solutions,
where it enables its customers to connect and interact with fixed and mobile assets, devices and a growing
catalogue of remote sensors in the field. Utilizing the O2 Group’s spectrum to provide big data solutions to its
customers, offering a range of secure, aggregated and anonymised data sets of population movement, profile,
preferences and trend analysis information, allowing customers to make informed decisions and develop their
business strategies.

As network technologies evolve and the O2 Group progresses the roll-out of 5G services, it works closely
with its enterprise and multinational customers to provide both dedicated 5G private networks solutions and a
wide range of innovative 5G applications and solutions, from virtual and augmented reality solutions, through to
digital twin technologies and spatial insights services, combining the power of 5G and IoT technologies and
applications to bring connected locations and venues to life.

For multinational customers, the O2 Group delivers services provided by both the U.K. business and other
Telefónica group companies to users and facilities in the U.K., including mobility, voice services, fixed
connectivity IoT connectivity, security, data analytics and international data connectivity.

The O2 Group offers ongoing management and support to its enterprise customers by providing dedicated
account management as well as solution design, monitoring and maintenance. Customer service advisors are
available to enterprise and multinational customers to address individual support queries.

The O2 Group’s fixed-line services are delivered through wholesale agreements with third parties. The O2
Group believes that it benefits from not having a large base of legacy fixed-line services allowing it to pursue its
customer-led, mobile-first approach and enabling its customers to adopt more flexible and collaborative working
behaviors.

The O2 Group’s focus on partnering with customers to build business solutions, has resulted in new
business from companies like The Very Group, Northumbrian Water, Sainsbury’s and McDonald’s. In the first
year of working with Sainsbury’s, the O2 Group was awarded Sainsbury’s Supplier Award for transformation of
its retail stores network.

**_Public sector_**

The O2 Group provides mobile and managed mobility services, data networks, cloud and security services
to the central government, local government and the voluntary sector in the U.K. The provision of services to the
public sector has been an area of focus of the O2 Group in recent years, and there has been a significant increase
in the number of the O2 Group’s public sector accounts.

The O2 Group provides services to the public sector through a number of public sector frameworks
including the Network Services Framework 2 RM3808 and G-Cloud 11 (replacement framework to the Network
Services Framework RM1045 and G-Cloud 10). The Network Services 2 Framework is an agreement to enable
public sector organizations to purchase a broad range of network connectivity and telecommunications services
from a range of ten individual lots covering different categories of services without the requirement to run a
lengthy full tendering exercise. As part of its customer-led, mobile-first approach, the O2 Group is developing
products and services designed to meet the specific needs of its public sector customers. For example, in 2020 the
O2 Group provided the NHS with tablets with mobile data enabling the NHS to create an end-to-end service and
help with public sector patient care especially during the COVID-19 pandemic as well as working with ENABLE
Scotland in deploying mobile devices and increasing financial and resourcing efficiencies.

In addition, the O2 Group obtained several information security standards, including Cyber Essentials (an
information assurance assessment framework developed by NCSC and Crest), ISO 27001 (the international
information security management standard for customer and employee data) and ISO 22301 (the international
business continuity standard), to help protect and grow the O2 Group’s public sector business. In addition, the O2
Group is implementing the Telecoms Security Requirements (which is expected to become a regulatory standard)
to ensure that it provides secure services that meet the U.K. Government’s and other public sector bodies’ future
expectations.

**_Value-add services and products_**

The O2 Group offers a number of value-add services and products as part of its strategy to increase
customer engagement and loyalty and reduce customer churn rates. The following value-add services and
products are available to the O2 Group’s customers:

 - _Rewards and offers: Priority offers customers a range of exclusive deals and offers through a mobile app, as_
well as access to digital presales of tickets for music, comedy and sports events across the O2 Group’s 20
sponsored venues in the U.K. up to 48 hours before general release. Priority is one of the largest U.K. digital
loyalty programs. Priority had over 2.6 million active users as of December 31, 2020, with more than
19.3 million offers being accepted and prize draws being entered through Priority in 2020 and
approximately 1.4 million Priority tickets sold in 2020. Prior to the onset of the COVID-19 Pandemic,
Priority had over 2.9 million active users as of December 31, 2019, with more than 34.5 million offers being
accepted and prize draws being entered through Priority in 2020 and over 3.8 million Priority tickets sold in
2019.

 - _Technical support: The O2 Group launched “O2 Gurus” in 2009 to provide technical and product advice to_
existing and potential customers in-store, online and over the phone.

 - _Wi-Fi: O2 Wi-Fi allows O2 Group customers, as well as non-O2 Group customers, to access free Wi-Fi at_
over 15,000 locations across the U.K. as of May 2021. O2 Wi-Fi was also developed to enable the O2
Group’s B2B customers (who can purchase O2 Wi-Fi and offer it to their customers and employees) to
provide their customers with an excellent customer experience within their venues. B2B customers can
choose to purchase additional services in relation to O2 Wi-Fi, including insight services whereby business
customers can learn more about their own customers, through data on, for example, footfall and
demographics. Business customers can also benefit from the O2 Gateway ecosystem and gain access to
additional services, for example increased network resilience by allowing essential services to function on
Wi-Fi in the event that their WAN fails. The O2 Group believes that O2 Wi-Fi is the leading urban public
network. It is offered free to end users regardless of their end network and, with approximately 6.3 million
unique users as of March 31, 2021, and 9.8 million unique users in February 2020 (prior to the COVID-19
related U.K. lockdown), it allows the O2 Group to access a wider potential customer base and introduce
potential O2 Group customers to the O2 brand and its core business.

 - _Communications: Wi-Fi Calling (also called Voice over Wi-Fi or VoWi-Fi), allows customers to make and_
receive calls even if they cannot connect to the mobile network. 4G Calling (also called Voice over LTE or
VoLTE) allows customers to make calls using its 4G network, for a clearer voice call. In 4G Calling areas,
Wi-Fi and 4G Calling work together to provide a seamless and uninterrupted experience as customers move
from one to another, without calls being dropped.

 - _Payment services: Charge to Mobile allows customers to buy digital content through their handset, with the_
cost of the product added to their monthly mobile bill for “pay monthly” customers or taken from their
mobile credit for “pay as you go” customers.

 - _MyO2: MyO2 is an app enabling Enterprise, SMB and Consumer customers to check their bill, add or_
change the services they take from O2, or to deal with simple issues. It is the most popular customer
destination and the highest volume service channel where customers are choosing to self-serve rather than
use traditional customer service channels. Customers can view personalized tariff and device
recommendations if they are close to requiring an upgrade. SMBs have a dedicated service team with a
sector focus.

 - _O2 Extras: The O2 Group launched O2 Extras in partnership with, among others, Amazon, Cafeyn and_
MelodyVR. O2 Extras gives O2 Group customers the ability to pick a selected product provided by one of
its partners to enjoy alongside all the usual benefits of their tariff. In March 2020, the O2 Group expanded
its O2 Extra offering and signed an exclusive agreement with Disney and became the only U.K. mobile
network operator to offer Disney+ subscription to its customers.

The O2 Group also offers paid services and products with the aim of leveraging the O2 Group’s strong
position in the U.K. mobile service market and monetizing additional growth opportunities, including (i) mobile
and tablet insurance, (ii) international calling bolt-ons which allow customers to make international calls from 1p
per minute for £3 per month, and (iii) the O2 Travel bolt-on, which allows customers to call, text and use data at
significantly reduced rates (compared with the O2 Group’s standard rates) while roaming abroad.
