**_Digital services_**

The O2 Group is continually evolving its business model and developing new digital products and services
including personalized customer offerings and rewards, with the aim of playing a broader role in its customers’
digital lives while delivering a differentiated customer experience. The O2 Group’s development of new digital
products and services is led by its customer-led, mobile-first strategy. The O2 Group aims to improve the
customer experience by providing products and services tailored to the needs of consumers and businesses (such
as unified communication and collaboration services, cloud services and managed network segments) and to use
the O2 Group’s significant customer base and information assets to diversify revenue beyond the O2 Group’s
traditional mobile service provisions.

**_Internet of Things_**

The O2 Group offers products and services in the IoT (which includes activities sometimes referred to as
“machine-to-machine” or “M2M”) which provides automated data communications between devices (including
vehicle fleets, payment terminals and traffic lights) via its mobile network, to help businesses reduce costs and
grow revenue through greater convenience and improved customer experience.

In 2013, the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy of the U.K. Government awarded the
O2 Group a 15-year contract initially worth approximately £1.5 billion to deliver communications services
(including the supply of communication hubs) for 23 million homes in the central and southern regions of the
U.K. as part of the Smart Metering Implementation Program (“SMIP”), one of the largest IoT projects in the
world. SMIP has been rolling out millions of gas and electricity smart meters across the U.K. to help reduce
energy usage and CO2 emissions by providing greater visibility of energy consumption. The O2 Group is a core
communications service provider within SMIP, and the program is a key part of the U.K.’s drive towards a low
carbon economy and supports the goal of being carbon neutral as a country by 2050.

**_Commerce_**

The O2 Group uses its large and growing customer base of mobile customers and registered O2 Wi-Fi users
to diversify its revenue beyond traditional mobile services. This includes the following commerce services which
are currently offered by the O2 Group:

    - _Insights: The O2 Group offers a suite of big-data driven insights services, which aim to help businesses_
understand their customers and improve their customer engagement and sales strategy. The O2 Group’s
insight services use aggregated, anonymized data from the O2 Group’s opted-in customers and users to
offer accurate and targeted information to businesses.

    - _Messaging: O2 helps businesses engage with their customers and employees by enabling them to send_
automated text messages.

**_giffgaff, Tesco Mobile and Wholesale Partners_**

In addition to its business under the premium O2 brand, the O2 Group has a wholly-owned digital brand,
giffgaff, and a joint venture, Tesco Mobile. In addition, the O2 Group is the leading wholesale provider in the
U.K. in terms of the number of MVNO subscribers (including Tesco Mobile, Sky Mobile, Lycamobile, Truphone
and Manx Telecom), providing wholesale MVNO partners access to the O2 Group’s mobile network and
infrastructure which enables MVNOs to provide mobile telecommunications services to their customers.
Through these arrangements, the O2 Group seeks to expand its reach across the U.K. telecommunications market
and access additional complementary customer groups, including loyal Tesco customers (such as Tesco Clubcard
holders) through the joint venture with Tesco, and expatriate communities through the MVNO partnership with
Lycamobile.

_giffgaff_

giffgaff is a 100% owned subsidiary within the O2 Group, and is an online-only MVNO providing
telecommunications services to the consumer mobile segment. It has no call centers or shops, resulting in a
highly-efficient member service model with significantly reduced customer service costs. giffgaff’s core business
is the provision of pre-pay, SIM only mobile services, but it also offers new and refurbished handsets (outright or
via a loan from our finance partner). As of March 31, 2021, giffgaff’s member base was approximately
4.5 million.

126


-----

_Tesco Mobile_

Tesco Mobile is a 50:50 joint venture between certain subsidiaries of Tesco and the O2 Group providing
mobile services in the U.K. The business has continually grown and developed, and is now the largest MVNO in
the U.K. in terms of mobile subscribers, offering a full range of pre-pay and post-pay mobile services (both
SIMO or with a handset).

Tesco Mobile offers its services and products across multiple channels, including through extensive national
store coverage as part of Tesco stores, together with telesales and online sales. A significant number of Tesco
Mobile’s customers are also Tesco Clubcard holders. As of March 31, 2021, Tesco Mobile had approximately
5.1 million customers.

_Lycamobile_

Lycamobile considers itself to be one of the world’s largest international MVNOs with 16 million customers
in 23 countries worldwide. Lycamobile targets expatriate communities in the U.K., primarily through its
international “pay as you go” SIM cards which provide low cost international calls. The O2 Group last renewed
its MVNO agreement with Lycamobile in 2021.

_Sky_

Sky, the largest U.K. pay-television broadcaster, entered into an exclusive, multi-year MVNO agreement
with the O2 Group in 2015, allowing Sky to offer mobile services in addition to the fixed-line telephony, fixedline broadband internet and television services that it already offered to its customers. The O2 Group’s MVNO
agreement with Sky was extended on a long-term basis in 2021.

**Network Infrastructure**

**_Mobile network_**

The O2 Group operates a mobile access network based on 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G standards. As of March 31,
2021, the O2 Group’s network sharing arrangement with Vodafone consisted of more than 17,300 shared mobile
sites (in addition to those operated separately by the O2 Group) with 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G base stations
(connecting handsets to the O2 Group’s mobile network using available spectrum), backhaul (the transport link
between the mobile sites and the O2 Group’s core network), the core network (composed of data centers which
store customer information and location and switching sites which route voice calls and data to their intended
destination) and a service layer (which provides messaging and voicemail capabilities).

The O2 Group has a comprehensive 4G mobile network across the U.K. extending to over 99% outdoor
population coverage as of March 31, 2021.

Vodafone, the O2 Group expects to be able to actively roll out the 5G network faster than would otherwise be
possible. The O2 Group believes itself to be well placed to continue its 5G roll-out notwithstanding the U.K.
Government’s decision to remove all Huawei equipment from 5G networks by the end of 2027.

The O2 Group’s network strategy focuses on coverage and reliability, which it believes are the two key
factors that customers value with respect to a mobile network. The O2 Group believes that this customer-led,
mobile-first strategy has been instrumental in helping it establish a leading position in the U.K. mobile
telecommunications market as well as high customer loyalty, demonstrated by O2 winning the Best Network for
Coverage award (for the fourth year running) and giffgaff winning Network of the Year in the 2021 uSwitch
Mobile Awards, both as voted for by members of the public.

_Network coverage and reliability_

The O2 Group has aimed to continually improve its network coverage and reliability to deliver a world-class
service for its customers.

The O2 Group invests in its network to help its customers, remain competitive and exploit the potential that
5G technology can provide. The O2 Group’s network sharing arrangement with Vodafone creates a single,
national grid of more than 17,300 shared mobile sites across the U.K. as of March 31, 2021, which provides
comprehensive network coverage and will allow more people to access 5G technology faster than would
otherwise be possible. See “—Backhaul and Transport—Network sharing arrangement between Vodafone
_Limited and Telefonica UK Limited” below for more information._

The O2 Group has invested in obtaining a significant share of the lower frequency spectrum which helps it
achieve greater coverage both indoor and outdoor (see “—Licenses and frequencies” below). The O2 Group has
licenses for approximately 36% of the sub 1 GHz spectrum compared to approximately 26% licensed to
Vodafone, 24% licensed to EE/BT and 14% licensed to Three. Lower frequency spectrum can travel longer
distances than higher frequency spectrum and pass more easily through walls, increasing indoor and outdoor
coverage.

The O2 Group regularly conducts independent drive testing of its network, performing a series of voice calls
and mobile data tests to ensure these represent a true customer experience. Reports are produced against a
number of key performance indicators including call completion success rates and data speeds. The O2 Group
also crowdsources information from Tutela. This information enables a technical comparison against the O2
Group’s competitors and a customer experience view of the O2 network.

The resilience of the O2 network has been demonstrated in light of the COVID-19 pandemic. As of April
2020, phone calls increased 25%, with the first week of the U.K. lockdown seeing a 57% peak increase in calls
carried across the O2 network. Following the return of Premier League football on June 17, 2020, nationwide
data usage surged by 13% at 8pm as the first games were played. As of March 31, 2021, the O2 network had
successfully managed the increase in traffic of all kinds without major incident.

_Capacity and spectrum management_

Spectrum licenses are currently divided between the four MNOs active in the U.K. mobile
telecommunications service market, with approximately 32% of allocated spectrum licensed to EE/BT,
approximately 24% licensed to Vodafone, approximately 22% licensed to Three and approximately 22% licensed
to O2.

The O2 Group undertakes a number of measures to manage and expand its network capacity and ensure that
the O2 Group has sufficient capacity to meet customer demand. The O2 Group is building small cell sites to
increase capacity particularly in built-up areas where there is not enough room for full scale mast sites. The O2
Group has an ongoing refarming process designed to ensure the most efficient use of its spectrum assets,
specifically—the O2 Group is reducing the spectrum used by its 2G and 3G networks to a minimum, and will be
looking to maximize the spectrum available to its 4G and 5G networks. In April 2021, Ofcom held a spectrum
auction of 700 MHz and 3.6 - 3.8GHz bands, which are suitable for 4G and 5G. Telefonica UK Limited acquired
20 MHz of paired 700 MHz FDD spectrum and 40 MHz of 3.6 - 3.8 GHz spectrum. As part of the same auction,
Telefonica UK Limited agreed to trade holdings in the 3.4 - 3.8 GHz band with Vodafone in order to allow it to
defragment its spectrum and create a contiguous block of 80 MHz in the same band. This is in addition to the 25
MHz of the 2.6 GHz band Telefonica UK Limited acquired from EE in 2020. See “—Licenses and frequencies”
below for more information.

128


-----

In the future, the O2 Group may also be able to manage its network capacity through the successful
application of a variety of yield management techniques. See “Risk Factors—Our ability to meet growing
_customer demand for mobile services and to expand our business depends, in part, on the capacity, speed and_
_reliability of our mobile network which in turn depends on our ability to adequately manage network capacity_
_and usage levels, successfully implement capacity expansion and yield management strategies, and acquire_
_additional spectrum”._

_London capacity program_

The O2 Group’s London capacity program aims to transform and optimize the O2 Group’s network capacity
within London. The program uses a number of strategies to achieve this, including significant transfer of
frequencies in central London, deployment of small cell sites and strategically placed additional Wi-Fi hotspots
to offload capacity.

**_Backhaul and transport_**

_Backhaul services between the O2 Group’s mobile sites and core network_

Traffic is transported between the O2 Group’s mobile sites and its core network using a diverse portfolio of
backhaul solutions. These include optical links managed by BT and Virgin Media Communications Limited as
well as self-built wireless connections via point-to-point microwave systems. This approach provides the O2
Group with the ability to connect its mobile sites and core network quickly, flexibly and cost-effectively.

_Interconnections within the O2 Group’s core network_

The O2 Group’s core network is composed of a number of switching sites and data centers across the U.K.
In 2016, the O2 Group migrated to a dedicated high capacity “dark-fiber” network which improved the capacity
and scalability of the O2 Group’s core network allowing it to accommodate increasing demand for mobile data
driven by the O2 Group’s 4G roll-out and increasing data usage by the O2 Group’s customer base.

_Network sharing arrangement between Vodafone Limited and Telefonica UK Limited_

In 2012, Telefonica UK Limited and Vodafone entered into a network sharing arrangement under which
Telefonica UK Limited and Vodafone agreed to share their collective mobile sites to form a single, national grid
of mobile sites across the whole of the U.K. In 2019, Telefonica UK Limited and Vodafone announced a further
agreement to share 5G active equipment, such as radio antennae, on joint network sites in certain parts of the
U.K.

Under the network sharing arrangement, both Vodafone and Telefonica UK Limited (through a 50:50 joint
venture company, “CTIL”) have access to a single grid of more than 17,300 shared mobile sites as of March 31,
2021. Telefonica UK Limited has thus been able to decommission 3,575 mobile sites thereby reducing costs. The
network sharing agreement also requires the building of new mobile sites needed to extend coverage into rural
and remote areas or to increase capacity as required in relevant areas.

The network sharing arrangement has two distinct elements: a passive infrastructure share and an active
RAN share.

The passive infrastructure share is managed by CTIL into which Telefonica UK Limited and Vodafone
contributed their existing site management businesses (including the mobile sites and physical assets deployed on
the mobile sites which are used in association with the RAN). CTIL manages and provides the parties with access
to all mobile sites and passive RAN assets which form part of a single national grid. In January 2021, the O2
Group and Vodafone announced a new Master Services Agreement, which will provide for operational simplicity
and efficiency, and will enable CTIL to generate revenue by offering space on infrastructure to third parties.

The active RAN share component involves sharing of Telefonica UK Limited’s and Vodafone’s 2G, 3G, 4G
and 5G networks (except in London and certain other major cities). The shared network is managed by each party
separately based on a geographical split: Telefonica UK Limited is responsible for managing the active
component of the shared network in the Eastern half of the U.K., Northern Ireland, most of Scotland and North
London, and Vodafone is responsible for managing the active component of the shared network in the Western
half of the U.K. (including Wales) and South London.

129


-----

Each party acts as host operator in its allotted geographical region and, as such, in that region provides
active sharing services to the other party (the “sharing operator”). The parties’ responsibilities in their allocated
regions include the design, deployment, operation and maintenance of the active elements of the RAN. Backhaul
to and from the mobile sites is provided by the host operator. For each shared site, a single set of base station
equipment transmits signals at the host operator’s frequencies (for the host’s traffic) and at the sharing operator’s
frequencies (for the sharer’s traffic) using 2G, 3G,4G and 5G technologies as required by the sharer (in London
only 4G is currently actively shared, which is set to stop following mutual agreement, and 5G will similarly not
be shared in London and certain other cities). In its region, the host operator operates two separate RANs: (i) a
host RAN for its own traffic; and (ii) a managed RAN for the sharing operator’s traffic, using shared passive
physical equipment managed across the U.K. by CTIL.

As part of these arrangements, the parties entered into a managed network services agreement which sets out
an agreed target number of shared mobile sites forming the single grid including contractual deployment
milestones with minimum network capabilities and performance standards. Together these elements constitute
the “basic demand” which determines the coverage, capacity and capability which the host operator must provide
to the sharing operator. Each party may request further coverage, capacity or capability anywhere in the U.K.
which exceeds this basic demand. If the other party wants to share that additional coverage, capacity or capability
it is provided by the host operator for the use of both parties; otherwise it will be provided unilaterally for the
sharing operator.

**_Licenses and frequencies_**

The O2 Group has the following spectrum holdings: 2 x 10 MHz of 800 MHz, 2 x 17.4 MHz of 900 MHz,
2 x 5.8 MHz of 1.8 GHz and 2 x 10 MHz of 2.1 GHz, in addition to the 40 MHz of 2.3 GHz, 3.4 GHz and
3.6 GHz spectrum referred to below. The O2 Group’s spectrum licenses are effective until revoked by Ofcom or
surrendered by the O2 Group.

Although no license or authorization is required to operate a telecommunications network or provide a
telecommunications service in the U.K., operators must obtain a license under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 2006
in order to use radio frequency spectrum.

Spectrum licenses for an agreed block of spectrum can be awarded by auction or through negotiation with
Ofcom. However, Ofcom’s established policy has been to use auctions as a means of allocating spectrum. In
2018 Ofcom completed a mobile spectrum auction pursuant to which licenses were awarded in 2.3 GHz and
3.4 GHz bands suitable for 4G and 5G deployment. The O2 Group was awarded licenses to 2350 - 2390 MHz
(2.3 GHz) and 3500 - 3540 MHz (3.4 GHz) of spectrum following the 2018 auction. In 2020, Telefonica UK
Limited acquired 25 MHz of the 2.6 GHz spectrum band from EE. In April 2021, Ofcom completed a mobile
spectrum auction of the 700 MHz and 3.6 - 3.8 GHz bands pursuant to which the O2 Group was awarded a paired
licence covering 703 - 713 MHz and 758 - 768 MHz (700 MHz) and 3760 - 3800 (3.6 GHz). As part of the same
auction, O2 Group agreed to trade holdings in the 3.4 - 3.8 GHz band with Vodafone, in order to allow it to
defragment its spectrum and create a contiguous block of 80 MHz.

The O2 Group intends to review all opportunities for additional future spectrum in order to improve
capacity on its network and enhance its ability to deliver high-quality mobile services. The analysis of future
spectrum opportunities and the management of network capacity and usage levels are, and are expected to
continue to remain, key strategic priorities for the O2 Group.

**Brand and Marketing**

**_Brand and marketing_**

The O2 brand is at the heart of the O2 Group’s business. The O2 brand was founded on the idea that mobile
connectivity is like oxygen: essential for life.

The O2 Group engages in a variety of marketing activities, both paid and unpaid. The O2 Group advertises
its premium O2 brand through a range of media channels including national television, radio, print, online and
outdoor advertising, and uses social media to raise awareness of the O2 brand. The O2 Group increasingly uses
online marketing and social media to build interest in its products. The O2 Group believes that integrating sales
activity with innovative proposition development and creative campaigns has helped it increase its market share
in SMB and enterprise businesses and the public sector.

130


-----

In 2019, the O2 Group implemented Net Promoter Score (“NPS”) supporting the O2 Group’s strategy to
improve its customer experience by listening to customers and delivering the best possible experience to create
true brand advocates. NPS measures the willingness of customers to recommend a company to others. The O2
Group maintained its market-leading position in overall NPS ending 2020 with a score of 29.

The O2 Group believes that its brand strategy has helped grow its customer base and maintain customer
loyalty resulting in market-leading total revenue growth.

**_Intellectual property rights_**

The “O2”, “O2 Refresh” and “Priority” brands and related rights (the “O2 Brand Rights”) are licensed to
Telefonica UK Limited for use in the U.K. under an indefinite trademark license. The license is royalty-free but
it is granted in consideration of Telefonica UK Limited paying for certain general and specific brand costs
according to a separate cost sharing agreement.

The “giffgaff” brand and trademarks are owned by Telefonica UK Limited. The “Tesco Mobile” brand is
owned by Tesco Stores Limited and licensed to the joint venture.

**_Sponsorship_**

O2 partners with organizations and businesses as part of its brand strategy to raise the brand’s profile and
appeal to new and existing customers. For over a decade the O2 Group’s Sponsorship portfolio has focused on
three long-term deals: AEG (The O2), RFU (England Rugby) and Live Nation (O2 Academy venues and Priority
Tickets).

In 2007, the O2 Group became the sponsor of The O2 in London, rebranding and transforming the
Millennium Dome into an entertainment venue. The O2 has since become the most popular entertainment venue
in the world, selling over 25 million tickets in the fourteen years since its launch, and is consistently one of the
top-selling entertainment venues globally each year. The O2 generates significant media value for the O2 Group
by providing free coverage for the O2 brand through the press, online and TV viewing and through attendance at
events at The O2.

The O2 Group also sponsors a number of other well-known music venues including O2 Academy Brixton,
O2 Shepherds Bush Empire and O2 Academy Glasgow, to form a network of O2 Academy branded music
venues. As of May 7, 2020, there were 20 O2 Academy venues across 13 cities in the U.K. which attracted over
3.2 million visitors to more than 3,300 music events in 2019 prior to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic.

**Sales and Distribution**

**_Direct channels_**

The O2 Group continues to move towards an omni-channel sales approach for its direct sales, offering
customers the ability to research, purchase and collect products through three primary sales channels: stores (both
O2-owned and franchised), online and telesales. The O2 Group has increasingly focused on delivering an
integrated and seamless experience across different elements of its direct distribution channels. The O2 Group
believes that these omni-channel offerings help it achieve high customer engagement, higher value customers
and high customer satisfaction.

Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, O2-owned franchise stores were traditionally the largest direct sales
channels. As of December 31, 2020, the O2 Group offered its products and services through 436 stores (233
O2-owned stores and 203 franchise stores). O2-owned stores and franchise stores are generally located in highly
frequented and strategically important areas, such as high streets in urban centers, and offer exclusively O2
branded services. The O2 Group estimates that O2-owned and franchise stores had in aggregate approximately
1.4 million visitors per month during the year ended December 31, 2019 and approximately 0.8 million visitors
per month during the year ended December 31, 2020, with the decrease attributable to the U.K. lockdowns in
response to the COVID-19 pandemic. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic the O2 Group has revamped its
physical store presence with new layouts and a virtual queuing system to save customer waiting time. The result
is a more personal service which also reduces customer waiting time.

131


-----

The O2 Group conducts sales to Small Office / Home Office (“SOHO”) customers through its existing O2
direct sales and distribution channels (stores, online and telesales), using specialist sales advisors to help deliver
customer retention, acquisition and upgrades. The O2 Group conducts sales to SMB customers primarily through
a team of desk-based digital advisors and acquisition and sales specialists. The O2 Group conducts sales to
enterprise customers using field-based account management and acquisition teams as well as specialist sales
advisors and conducts sales to public sector customers through a dedicated public sector team.

The O2 Group also sells products and services directly through the O2 website and the MyO2 mobile app.
The O2 website has a specific business site in addition to its consumer site, with a dedicated online shop for SMB
customers. The O2 website had an average of 33.0 million visits per month during the year ended December 31,
2020, and there were approximately 11.2 million visits per month in the same period to the MyO2 mobile app.

In addition, the O2 Group sells products through telesales, and there were approximately 1.2 million
contacts per month during the year ended December 31, 2020.

**_Indirect channels_**

The O2 Group uses indirect channels as a means of increasing its customer reach and as a supplement to the
O2 Group’s direct distribution channels. The O2 Group has three indirect B2B sales and distribution channels:
business partners, distributors and wholesale partners. O2 business partners enter into an exclusive contract with
the O2 Group to sell mobile, fixed-line and digital services to predominantly SMB customers. The O2 Group
uses two key distributors (Digital Wholesale Solution and Carphone Warehouse Business) who manage a
network of stockists to sell O2 products and services to SMB customers. The O2 Group has a number of
wholesale partners who sell O2 mobile services under their own brand and bill customers directly.

**Customer Service**

The O2 Group is committed to providing an excellent end-to-end customer experience. In Ofcom’s
“Comparing Service Quality” Report of August 21, 2020, the O2 Group was joint first with another MNO (ahead
of Vodafone) for customer service satisfaction. In the latest Ofcom “Comparing Customer Service” Report of
May 7, 2021, the O2 Group was the second highest ranked MNO overall, with giffgaff having the highest
satisfaction with service overall of the assessed MNOs and MVNOs. The O2 Group was one of the top two
MNOs receiving the fewest Ofcom complaints (along with EE), as ranked by Ofcom in both of the
aforementioned reports. The O2 Group has significant outsourcing partnerships in connection with its customer
service offering.

In order to effectively manage customer credit risks, the O2 Group has a series of business acceptance
procedures including identity verification, credit and fraud checks and affordability assessments. The O2 Group
has collections policies in place to ensure that customers who are struggling to make payments are treated fairly.
The O2 Group’s arrears management process follows the general principles of treating customers as individuals,
contacting customers at the earliest opportunity, focusing on achieving the best outcome for the customer and
being aware of customer vulnerabilities.

**IT Systems and Security**

The O2 Group operates a large-scale IT estate and portfolio to support its customers. The O2 Group uses a
range of tools to actively identify vulnerabilities in its platforms and systems and deploys systems, tools and
analytics to tackle intrusion and secure the O2 Group’s network perimeter. Following a high profile cyberattack
on another market participant in 2015, the O2 Group launched a cyber defense program aimed at further
improving the strength of the O2 Group’s security systems and the O2 Group continues to recognize cyber
security as one of its greatest areas of risk.

**Environment**

The O2 Group’s activities, similar to any other telecommunications company, has an impact on the
environment and can be impacted by climate change. The environmental and climate change risks of the O2
Group are controlled and managed under a global risk management model. The material environmental risks of
the O2 Group include the risks of flooding and business interruption as a result of climate change that are
associated with the O2 Group’s high geographic dispersion of infrastructure, of which such risks are mitigated
through its environmental management based processes and have been certified according to the ISO 14001
standard and business continuity plans, as further described below.

In addition, the O2 Group specifically analyzes and manages its risks and opportunities as a result of climate
change in accordance with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate Related Financial Disclosures. In
order to manage its risks, the O2 Group has put in place strategies to help increase its resilience to climate
change, including by planning for and adapting to both the physical consequences of climate change and the
changes arising from a transition to a low carbon economy. The main measures included in the O2 Group’s
mitigation plans are (i) its business continuity plans in case of climate disasters, (ii) its energy efficiency and
renewable energy plans, which enable the O2 Group to reduce its power consumption, fossil fuel consumption
and greenhouse gas emissions, and (iii) its wider plans relating to the transition to a low carbon economy that
take into account regulatory, technological, market and reputational risks.

In 2020, the O2 Group updated its Blueprint sustainability commitments with a focus on building a greener
network, including goals of removing non-renewable energy across its network and operations to become a net
zero business by 2025. The O2 Group is also committed to reducing its carbon emissions by at least 39% across
its value chain by 2025, and to deliver a net zero value chain by 2040.

In October 2020, Telefonica UK Limited was re-certified to the Carbon Trust’s Triple Standard, which is
awarded to companies that demonstrate success in cutting their carbon, water and waste footprints. Telefonica
UK Limited, as a subsidiary of Telefónica, has also been recognized for its high quality disclosure of its
environmental impacts by virtue of Telefónica being included on the Carbon Disclosure Project’s climate change
“A list” from 2017 to 2020. See also “Summary—O2 Group Overview—Sustainability Strategy of the O2
_Group”._

**Property and leases**

As at December 31, 2020, the O2 Group operated through 436 stores around the U.K. (233 O2-owned stores
and 203 franchise stores), 17 technical sites and large office sites in Leeds and Preston Brook as well as its head
office at 260 Bath Road, Slough, U.K.

Under the network sharing arrangement between the companies, both Vodafone and Telefonica UK Limited
(through CTIL, the 50:50 joint venture company) have access to a single grid of more than 17,300 shared mobile
sites as of March 31, 2021. CTIL holds almost all of the mobile sites (either wholly or by holding space on the
site) under operating lease agreements.

**Insurance**

The O2 Group maintains insurance coverage in line with industry practice. The O2 Group is insured for,
among other things, material damage and business interruption, known all risk insurance including cyber risk and
crime, corporate/general/public liability, products liability, property damage, environmental liability, errors and
omission, terrorism, patent infringement, pension trustee liability, motor fleet insurance, employer’s liability and
directors’ and officers’ liability. The O2 Group has coverage under a Personal Accident and Travel policy, and a
U.K. Warehouse Policy.

**Legal Proceedings**

From time to time, the O2 Group has become involved in litigation relating to claims arising out of our
operations in the normal course of business.

The O2 Group has been addressing a request for disclosure made by governmental authorities which is
related to possible violations of anti-bribery laws and regulations. The O2 Group continues to co-operate with the
governmental authorities investigating this matter which is still ongoing. Also the O2 Group continues to conduct
its own internal investigation on the matter. Whilst it is not possible at this time to predict the full scope or
duration of this matter or its eventual outcome, the O2 Group considers it can make a reliable estimate of the
outcome and has made an accrual for this amount at March 31, 2021 and December 31, 2020.

Legal proceedings have been issued in the High Court against the O2 Group by the Administrators of
Phones 4u. The O2 Group has vigorously denied the allegations and filed its defense to this claim in April 2019.
No provision has been made in relation to this matter.

**SUSTAINABILITY OF THE O2 GROUP**

In this “Sustainability of the O2 Group”, the terms “we,” “our,” “our company,” and “us” refers to the O2
Group, unless otherwise stated.

The following discussion contains certain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties.
The O2’s actual results could differ materially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements. Factors
that could cause or contribute to such differences include those discussed below and elsewhere in this offering
memorandum, particularly in the sections entitled “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors”.

**Overview**

The O2 Group has a sustainability strategy (the “Blueprint Strategy”). The Blueprint Strategy was
launched in August 2020 and includes long-term targets to reflect the O2 Group’s commitment to reduce its
impact on the environment, and deliver a greener network for customers, by promoting the enabling role of
mobile in delivering a more sustainable future. It sets out its responsibility to society by helping people enjoy a
safer and more positive relationship with technology, and by improving digital access and inclusion. The
Blueprint Strategy also reflects the O2 Group’s commitment to running its business responsibly for its customers,
its people and other key stakeholders, by championing diversity and inclusion, and by building an ethical culture
and maintaining strong community ties.

The Blueprint Strategy has three primary commitments:

    - **Building a greener future by becoming a net zero business by 2025 (with the goal that the O2**
Group’s value chain reduce its emissions by 39% by 2025 and achieve net zero emissions by 2040) and
offering mobile and digital innovation to customers to make a low-carbon world a reality;

    - **Helping society thrive by promoting greener, more inclusive and resilient communities powered by**
smart technology; and

    - **Leading by example by championing a fair and ethical business from the inside as an inclusive**
employer and adopting ethical decision making as well as creating shared accountability.

The Blueprint Strategy is aligned with, and contributes to, eight of the United Nations’ Sustainable
Development Goals, which aim to tackle pressing global challenges such as climate change, injustice and
equality, namely:

    - Promoting the use of affordable, safe, sustainable and modern energy for all;

    - Supporting sustainable consumption and production models;

    - Taking urgent action to fight climate change and its impacts;

    - Boosting connectivity and fostering innovation;

    - Reducing inequality and championing inclusion;

    - Enabling communities to benefit from the development and use of smart technologies;

    - Achieving gender equality; and

    - Promoting sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth and decent work for all.

The Blueprint Strategy is also underpinned by a commitment to operating responsibly in everything the O2
Group does. The Blueprint Strategy’s core values of “Bold, Open and Trusted” (representing the O2 Group’s
bold attitude, openness to its customers and people and its strong emphasis on earning the trust of its people and
customers) and its business principles (which form the O2 Group’s ethical code) help guide behaviours at all
levels of the organisation.

135


-----

**Environment: Building a greener future**

We plan to reduce emissions, do what we can to protect the environment and encourage as many people as
we can to reduce their impact through digital connectivity. We believe that mobile technology can deliver
environmental benefits for society that outweigh our own impacts, by helping to make it easier for our business
partners, suppliers and customers to make more sustainable choices. We launched a Green Savings Calculator to
help businesses identify ways to reduce their carbon footprint and save money with long-term flexible working.
The Green Savings Calculator finds annual savings of 534 tonnes of carbon and £2.6 million on energy, property
and travel costs for an average U.K. PLC with 1,000 employees, and an overall estimated £53 billion saving.

Our goal for our own operations to be net zero by 2025 is an ambitious undertaking, but we believe in the
importance of taking timely and decisive action to combat climate change. Our commitment is aligned to the
Science Based Targets initiative (“SBTi”), which assists companies in setting emission reduction goals in line
with the Paris Agreement, and goes beyond the initiative’s steps necessary to support a limitation of global
warming to 1.5ºC. In addition, we are working in partnership with the Carbon Trust to develop a clear roadmap
to achieve our net zero goal. In 2020, we published a whitepaper “The journey to net zero” which outlines a fivestep process to creating a net zero framework, and details our plans, progress, and learnings so far, with advice
and support to help other businesses join us on the journey.

We aim to remove all possible non-renewable energy usage across our business and network. Our network
is already powered by 100% renewable energy, wherever we directly control the energy bill. For masts and sites
where we do not have operational control, we are working with our landlords to promote the switch to renewable
energy. We carried out 732 site surveys in 2020 and will use the results to inform our activities in 2021 as we
continue to influence the transition to renewable energy.

We are also undertaking multiple energy efficiency measures, including advanced automation, and “turn
off” technology on our networks when demand is low, LED lighting upgrades, and enhanced free air-cooling
processes. The implementation of such energy efficiency measures have resulted in an 82% overall improvement
in our energy efficiency since 2015. Additionally, we partnered with SSE Business Energy and launched a new
offer for all O2 suppliers and business partners in the U.K., giving them the chance to buy SSE Green renewable
electricity at an exclusive rate. Our carrier partners deployed 730 electric vehicles for our deliveries at depots
across the U.K. by the end of 2020.

In addition to the O2 Group being certified to the environmental management system ISO 14001, Telefonica
UK Limited is also certified to the Carbon Trust’s Triple Standard for carbon, water and waste management. We
are always looking for ways to remove or reduce our plastic use, both in our offices and in our stores. We do not
use plastic bags in our shops, we have reduced the plastic used in SIM-card packaging and encouraged the use of
re-usable tableware in our offices as well as recycling uniforms in our stores.

Our customers can use our Eco Rating scheme to find out more about the social and environmental impact
of our handset range or to recycle their old devices with O2 Recycle, thereby extending the life of mobile phones
and helping to save waste from going to landfill. We also work closely with our suppliers to help them set carbon
goals: currently, over 20% of our supply chain have agreed to carbon emission reduction plans. Through our
returns, repairs and recycling partners, we have delivered an average of 10% year on year reduction in carbon
emissions for the devices we have processed. We also encourage suppliers to reduce their reliance on single-use
plastics, to use renewable energy, and to proactively manage sustainability within their own supply chain.

**Social: Helping society thrive**

We want to keep communities connected by making our products and services accessible to everyone and
by helping people enjoy a safer and more positive experience with technology. We focus our efforts around
causes that link to the social responsibilities we face as a business. We believe that everyone should be able to
safely access our products and services, and we strive to ensure that we support the most vulnerable members of
the communities in which we operate.

The COVID-19 pandemic underlined the importance of equal access to digital connectivity. As a result, we
established a new Community Calling scheme with environmental charity Hubbub to refurbish and gift
smartphones and tablets to the most vulnerable people in six cities across the U.K. Working in partnership with
local community organisations and reputable charities, we are offering devices to those most in need, plus 12
months of free connectivity including unlimited minutes, unlimited texts and 6GB of data per month.

136


-----

We are also collaborating with the U.K. government and other mobile providers to deliver a Shared Rural
Network that will reach every part of the U.K., promoting digital inclusion and ensuring that the benefits of
connectivity can be enjoyed by everyone.

Our partnership with the U.K.’s leading child protection charity, the National Society for the Prevention of
Cruelty to Children (“NSPCC”), continues to focus on keeping families and children safe online. We offer online
safety initiatives, such as Net Aware, which provides advice and support in relation to the most popular apps,
games and websites used by children. In 2020, we delivered 681,301 social impacts through our partnership with
the NSPCC, which is how we describe ways in which we have helped people have a healthier, more positive
relationships with technology through the tools, program, products and services we offer. Our Content Standards
Policy covers our approach to content classification, age-verification, and the work we do with the Internet
Watch Foundation to block illegal content.

**Governance: Leading by example**

We put responsibility at the heart of everything we do, by championing a fair, inclusive, and ethical
business, and we believe we maintain the highest standards in our own decision making. Our Responsible
Business Taskforce oversees our social, ethical and environmental impacts, identifying and prioritising the issues
that matter most to our business and stakeholders. It includes senior representatives from each business area, is
chaired by the Director of Corporate Affairs and reports directly to our board of directors. To increase our
employees’ commitment to achieving our sustainability ambitions, 20% of our employees’ annual variable
remuneration, including for our board members, are linked to sustainability issues.

Local risk registers are kept for all non-financial risks as part of the company-wide process. Identified risks
for online safety are managed through our age verification and content classification procedures. The key
environmental risks are associated with climate change including the continued availability of renewable energy
and the potential for floods to impact the delivery of our services.

Our employees are key in helping us deliver our responsible business goals. Each employee has an annual
Blueprint objective and is encouraged to fundraise and volunteer their time to support our key causes. For
example, such as by supporting Telefonica’s International Volunteering Week by making green pledges,

**SUSTAINABILITY OF THE VIRGIN MEDIA GROUP**

In this “Sustainability of the Virgin Media Group”, the terms “we,” “our,” “our company,” and “us” refers
to the Virgin Media Group, unless otherwise stated.

The following discussion contains certain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties.
The Virgin Media Group’s actual results could differ materially from those discussed in these forward-looking
statements. Factors that could cause or contribute to such differences include those discussed below and
elsewhere in this offering memorandum, particularly in the sections entitled “Forward-Looking Statements” and
“Risk Factors”.

**Overview**

The Virgin Media Group’s sustainability strategy (the “Meaningful Connections Plan”) was launched in
February 2021. This sustainability strategy seeks to utilise the influence of the Virgin Media brand, the skills and
capabilities of its employees and the strength of its network to promote positive societal and environmental
changes. The Virgin Media Group’s sustainability plan will focus on the following three core undertakings for
the next five years (the terms “we,” “our,” and “us” below refer to the Virgin Media Group and its consolidated
subsidiaries):

    - **Better for people: We are aiming to build a business where all our employees and customers feel a**
sense of belonging and that they are being supported. To support this aim, we are creating initiatives
that assist individuals from underrepresented communities to develop skills and access employment
opportunities.

    - **Better for communities: While digital connectivity has increased incrementally, loneliness and**
isolation continue to rise with it. We are looking to bring people and communities closer together by
harnessing the power of our network and brand to help 1.5 million people foster meaningful
connections within their communities by the end of 2025, and intend to focus on supporting unpaid
carers with their experiences of loneliness through a five year partnership with Carers UK. We consider
a connection as “meaningful” where it helps reduce loneliness and build a sense of community
belonging. We will also look to encourage local volunteering as a way of encouraging community
involvement.

    - **Better for the planet: In recognition of the growing effects of human industry on our planet, we are**
looking to shrink our own impact by committing to a zero waste and zero carbon future. We have set a
goal of reaching net zero carbon and zero waste across our operations by the end of 2025.

The Virgin Media Group’s plan is underpinned by:

    - **Better business: We are committed to running our business responsibly by looking beyond our**
proactive environmental and social impact programs and looking to foster positive social and
environmental changes in our quotidian business operations.

**Better for the Planet**

As a digital enabler that serves of customers millions across the U.K., our ultrafast connectivity has the
potential to significantly support the advancement of sustainability in our society by, for example, improving
conditions for home and remote working, promoting smart energy-saving technology in the home and supporting
intelligent transport systems.

We are also accelerating change within our own business and operations to make a zero carbon and zero
waste future a reality. Our goal is to achieve net zero carbon and zero waste operations by the end of 2025. We
have a strong track record of environmental performance, with continuous reductions in our carbon emissions
and improvements made on our waste disposal since 2014.

**_“Net zero” future—to achieve “net zero” operations by the end of 2025_**

The Virgin Media Group is committed to an approach that rewards both efficiency and investment in
renewable energy. To promote this approach we have set the following targets:

    - to reduce our operational carbon footprint by 25% from 2019 to end of 2025 by transitioning our fleet
to electrical vehicles, which would put us on track to support Liberty Global’s SBTi-approved target of
achieving a 50% operational carbon footprint energy reduction by 2030;

138


-----

    - to support investments in renewable energy and carbon reduction from the atmosphere by achieving
operations that are net zero by the end of 2025 through sourcing 100% of our electricity from
renewable energy and investing in carbon removal and offsetting schemes for our remaining carbon
emissions;

    - to work with our supply chain to reduce carbon emissions, with a particular focus on the lifecycle
impact of our products, in order to support Liberty Global’s SBTi-approved target to reduce its scope 3
emissions by 50% from 2019 to the end of 2030;

    - to support the decarbonization of the U.K. economy by providing connectivity to underpin a
low-carbon digital transformation, to support the roll out of on-street electric vehicle charging through
the “Liberty Charge” joint venture and to utilise our TV platform and partnerships to amplify and
encourage the streaming of engaging climate-related content; and

    - to abide by our operational commitment to implement science-based targets on climate in accordance
with the Responsible Media Form’s Media Climate Pact, that we became a signatory to in November
2020.

**_Nothing wasted—to become a “zero waste” operation by end of 2025_**

We understand our responsibility to address the waste that our operations produce, such as the waste that we
produce by providing millions of electrical products to customers’ homes, by managing logistical operations that
send equipment across the U.K., by continuously expanding our network cables, and by employing more than
11,000 employees across the U.K. We are committed to creating a more environmentally-friendly and circular
operational model where the materials that we use are re-used so that they never become waste. We expect to
save over 5,000 tonnes of waste by using recycled materials and by refurbishing and reusing returned customer
products. We have therefore set ourselves the following targets to be achieved by the end of 2025:

    - to reuse or recycle at least 95% of all waste created by our business operations;

    - for every broadband or TV product sent to our customers to either (i) contain at least 75% recycled
plastic content or (ii) be a refurbished product;

    - to reuse or recycle 100% of returned broadband and TV products;

    - to have 100% of customer packaging be recyclable and without containing any single use plastic; and

    - to work with our network expansion and field partners to set a target to reduce the amount of waste that
is produced by us when expanding our network cables.

**Climate Risk Assessment**

**_Regulations_**

One of the main regulations that we are subject to is the power standby regulation impacting our customer
premise equipment. This regulation impacts the quality of service we provide our customers. If not well managed
it can degrade the customer experience of our video, telephony, internet and other services. Another regulation
that we are subject is Article 8 of the Energy Efficiency Directive, which has now been transposed into U.K. law.
As a result of this regulation, there is an obligation for an audit of our energy consumption to be conducted. Such
audit is intended to identify energy saving opportunities which would further reduce energy consumption, the
associated greenhouse gas emissions, and save costs.

**_Acute Physical Risks_**

We consider our operations to be exposed to physical risks, largely related to the impact of weather-related
events. Similar to many North- and Western- European businesses we must be prepared to adapt to the growing
threats posed by storms, floods, hot summers and droughts and the associated increase in our insurance
premiums.

**_Chronic Physical Risks_**

Average temperatures are expected to rise due to climate change. Increasing temperatures and increases in
the frequency of extreme temperature events will have implications on the costs associated with running our
technical sites. Technical sites such as datacentres already require a significant amount of energy to cool the
equipment (up to 40% of the energy used in a technical site can be for operating the cooling systems). As
temperatures rise, so too will the amount of electricity needed to run our air conditioners for longer or more
frequently.
